'''Thomas David Heaton''' (born 15 April 1986) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for English club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
He began his professional career with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] but was unable to break into the first team and spent time on loan with [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]], [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] and [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], before joining Cardiff permanently after his release by Manchester United in July 2010. He then joined [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on a one-year deal with an option of a second year but turned it down in May 2013 in favour of a move to Burnley, whom he has represented in the Premier League, and captained for since 2015.
Formerly an international from under-16 to under-21 level, Heaton has been involved in senior [[England national football team|England]] squads since 2015, finally making his senior debut against [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]] on 27 May 2016 in a [[UEFA Euro 2016]] warm-up fixture.
==Club career== ===Manchester United=== Born in [[Chester]], Cheshire,<ref name=Hugman1011/> Heaton began his football career with [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]], for whom he played both in goal and in midfield, but, after making 20 appearances for the [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] Under-17 team in the previous two seasons, he signed for United as a trainee on 8 July 2002.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He became a regular in the Under-17 team during the 2002–03 season, and picked up an [[FA Youth Cup]] winner's medal despite playing second fiddle to [[Luke Steele (footballer)|Luke Steele]] throughout the entire competition.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He made his first appearance in the reserve team the following season, starting in a 3–1 home win over [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in the Premier Reserve League on 2 October 2003.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} At the end of the 2003–04 season, Heaton was named on the bench for the final of the [[Manchester Senior Cup]] against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], and won a winner's medal despite not taking the field.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
By the 2004–05 season, Heaton had become the first-choice goalkeeper for the Manchester United reserve team, and was named on the bench for [[Stan Ternent]]'s testimonial on 17 August 2004, coming on as a 76th-minute substitute for Luke Steele after Steele had earlier come on for [[Tim Howard]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} With Heaton in goal for 17 of the 28 [[Premier Reserve League]] North matches and 12 of the 22 [[Central League (football)|Central League]] matches, the team went on to win both league titles by nine and five points respectively.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Heaton's form for the reserves resulted in him being loaned out to [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] at the start of the [[2005–06 Swindon Town F.C. season|2005–06]], initially until 1 January 2006.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} During his time at Swindon, he played over 20 matches, saving a penalty on his debut, and was described as "one for the future" by manager [[Iffy Onuora]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He returned to Manchester United,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/player/42250/tom-heaton?season=2006|title=Tom Heaton Player Profile |work=ESPN FC |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref> but, after the recall of [[Ritchie Jones]] from [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]], Heaton was sent there for the rest of the season after United rebuffed an approach from [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Heaton spent the [[2007–08 Manchester United F.C. season|2007–08 season]] with the first team-squad at Manchester United, appearing on the bench when [[Edwin van der Sar]] was out due to injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/player/42250/tom-heaton?season=2007|title=Tom Heaton Player Profile |work=ESPN FC |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref>
====Cardiff City (loan)==== At the end of the 2007–08 season, Heaton agreed to move to [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on loan for the duration of the [[2008–09 Cardiff City F.C. season|2008–09 season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff sign Man Utd goalkeeper |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/7407805.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 May 2008 |accessdate=23 May 2008}}</ref> He was chosen as the club's first choice goalkeeper, above [[Peter Enckelman]], for the start of the season by manager [[Dave Jones (footballer, born 1956)|Dave Jones]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Terry |last=Phillips |title=Heaton wins Bluebirds keeper battle for Saints start |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/heaton-wins-bluebirds-keeper-battle-2157149 |work=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |date=8 August 2008 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He played in every match until late November, with the exception of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] third round tie against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], when he was replaced by Enckelman.<ref>{{cite news |title=Swansea 1–0 Cardiff |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7626773.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 September 2008 |accessdate=18 February 2009}}</ref> However, late on in Cardiff's 2–1 away defeat to [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] on 22 November 2008, Heaton picked up an injury and was forced off.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} The injury would go on to cost Heaton his place in the team as the club went unbeaten with Enckelman in goal for over two months.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
In February, Enckelman was forced to undergo knee surgery which saw Heaton return in goal on 16 February 2009, when he picked up the [[man of the match]] award in a 4–0 defeat at the hands of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} However, he tore his thigh muscle during the match, ruling him out for up to five weeks.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff rocked by keeper injury |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/7895288.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 February 2009 |accessdate=18 February 2009}}</ref> On his return, Heaton found himself on the bench behind loanee [[Stuart Taylor (footballer, born 1980)|Stuart Taylor]] but, following a 6–0 defeat against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]], he replaced Taylor for the final three matches of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/player/42250/tom-heaton?season=2008|title=Tom Heaton Player Profile |work=ESPN FC |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref> However, he was unable to keep Cardiff in the play-off places and he returned to Manchester United at the end of the season.<ref>Phillips, Terry (16 May 2009). [http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-set-offer-skippers-2105918 "Cardiff City set to offer skipper's armband to Roger Johnson"]. ''WalesOnline''. Media Wales. Retrieved 11 April 2017.</ref>
====Queens Park Rangers (loan)==== On 15 August 2009, Heaton was signed by [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on an emergency three-month loan deal, the terms of which allowed him to compete in the [[2009–10 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Exclusive: United keeper pens loan |url=http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10373~1754286,00.html |publisher=Queens Park Rangers F.C. |date=15 August 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306033024/http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10373~1754286%2C00.html |archivedate=6 March 2012 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Heaton's loan spell ended on 8 November 2009.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He made one first-team appearance during his loan, in the 1–0 defeat at [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the League Cup on 23 September 2009.<ref name=sb0910/>
====Rochdale (loan)==== After returning from QPR, Heaton joined [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] on 13 November 2009 until the end of December 2009.<ref>{{cite news |title=Heaton makes Dale switch |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11667_5692918,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |date=13 November 2009 |accessdate=13 November 2009}}</ref> He made his debut in a 3–2 loss against [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] on 14 November 2009.<ref name=sb0910/> The loan was then extended until 23 January 2010,<ref>{{cite web |title=Keeping Heaton on |url=http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10441~1917247,00.html |publisher=Rochdale A.F.C. |date=28 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723062351/http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10441~1917247%2C00.html |archivedate=23 July 2011 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> before a further extension pushed the end date back to 31 January.<ref>{{cite web |title=Keeper extends loan |url=http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10441~1944299,00.html |publisher=Rochdale A.F.C. |date=25 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128102446/http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10441~1944299%2C00.html |archivedate=28 January 2010 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> In his 12 appearances for Rochdale, Heaton conceded only ten goals – including four clean sheets – and finished on the losing team just once.<ref name=sb0910/>
====Wycombe Wanderers (loan)==== Heaton spent less than two weeks back at Manchester United before going back out on loan to [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] on 12 February 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wycombe sign keeper Tom Heaton from Manchester United |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wycombe_wanderers/8512842.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 February 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2010}}</ref> He went straight into the Wycombe starting line-up for their away match against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] the following day, which they drew 1–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Brentford 1–1 Wycombe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8494099.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 February 2010 |accessdate=13 February 2010}}</ref> Heaton made his second appearance for the Chairboys in their 0–0 draw against Southampton on Tuesday 23 February 2010.<ref name=sb0910/> He made a great save from a volley to keep the Chairboys on even terms with the Saints.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8497013.stm|title = Wycombe 0–0 Southampton|date = 23 February 2010|accessdate = 4 June 2017}} </ref>
===Return to Cardiff City=== [[File:Tom Heaton.jpg|thumb|upright|Heaton playing for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2011]]
Meeting with Manchester United manager [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]] on his future at the club amidst an expiring contract, Heaton declined an offer to stay at [[Old Trafford]], deciding instead to leave on free transfer in pursuit of regular playing time.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/19/tom-heaton-burnley-england-alex-ferguson |title=Burnley's Tom Heaton: 'It got heated for a minute or two with Alex Ferguson' |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=David |last=Hytner |date=19 August 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Following his release by United, Heaton agreed a deal on 15 June 2010 to return to Cardiff City on 1 July 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd goalkeeper Tom Heaton returns to Cardiff City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8742377.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 June 2010 |accessdate=15 June 2010}}</ref> He made his second debut in 4–1 win over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] in the League Cup on 11 August.<ref name=sb1011/> After first-choice goalkeeper [[David Marshall (footballer)|David Marshall]] suffered an elbow injury, Heaton established himself as Cardiff's new number starter.<ref name=sb1011/> In late February, however, he suffered a groin injury, so [[Jason Brown (footballer)|Jason Brown]] and [[Stephen Bywater]] were brought in as cover on loan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackburn keeper Jason Brown completes Cardiff loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/9412224.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 March 2011}}</ref> Upon his return, Heaton went into the team against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], where they won 4–1, their first win in four matches.<ref>{{cite news |title=Goalkeeper Tom Heaton fitness boost for Cardiff City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/9430040.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2011}}</ref> Heaton's performances during the 2010–11 season earned him the club's Young Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Morris |title=Player of the Year awards. The winners |url=http://www.cardiffcity-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/player_of_the_year_awards_the_winners_673599/index.shtml |work=Cardiff City Mad |publisher=Digital Sports Group |date=30 April 2011 |accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
Under new manager, [[Malky Mackay]], Heaton found himself as cover for David Marshall, but he played a key part in the club's [[2011–12 Football League Cup|League Cup]] run in which they reached the final thanks to two saves from Heaton in a semi-final [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]] against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He suffered an ankle injury just before the final, but he overcame the injury to start at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref name=sb1112/> Heaton followed his penalty heroics against Crystal Palace when he started the penalty shoot-out by pushing [[Steven Gerrard]]'s effort onto the bar, but he ultimately ended up on the losing team as Liverpool won the shoot-out 3–2.<ref name=leaguecup2012>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Cardiff 2–2 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17093419 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Despite the successful cup run, Heaton still found himself second string to Marshall and was released at the end of the season after rejecting a new contract in the Welsh capital.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tom Heaton, Lee Naylor and Paul Quinn leave Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18052140 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
===Bristol City=== In July 2012, Heaton held talks with [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] over a potential move; however, Watford's new owners decided to pull out of the move.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hornets drop Heaton deal |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12691/7870887/Hornets-drop-Heaton-deal |publisher=Sky Sports |date=5 July 2012 |accessdate=5 July 2012}}</ref> Later that month, Heaton went on trial with [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] during their pre-season training camp in Spain and they opened contract talks soon after.<ref>{{cite news |title=City in Heaton talks |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7928823/ |publisher=Sky Sports |date=23 July 2012 |accessdate=23 July 2012}}</ref> On 27 July, Heaton signed a one-year deal with the club, with the option for a further 12 months.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bristol City sign ex-Cardiff City goalkeeper Tom Heaton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19013441 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 July 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 18 August 2012, in a 1–0 defeat away to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19221320 "Nott'm Forest 1–0 Bristol City"]. BBC Sport. 18 August 2012. Retrieved 11 April 2017.</ref> A disappointing season in Bristol led to the club owning the worst defensive record in the league with 84 goals allowed, and they were relegated at the end of the season.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Heaton started 43 of Bristol City's 46 matches in the Championship that season, and was viewed as one the club's better players that season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/tom-heaton-great-professional-work-says-sean-o/story-19033783-detail/story.html |title=Tom Heaton was a great professional to work with, says Sean O'Driscoll |newspaper=Bristol Post |date=20 May 2013 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11726/8667370/bristol-city-goalkeeper-tom-heaton-not-ruling-out-staying-at-ashton-gate |title=Bristol City goalkeeper Tom Heaton not ruling out staying at Ashton Gate |publisher=Sky Sports |date=23 April 2013}}</ref>
===Burnley=== [[File:Tom Heaton watches proceedings.jpg|thumb|upright|Heaton playing for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in 2015]]
Heaton joined Burnley in May 2013, after turning down a further one-year deal at Bristol City.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} His decision was to stay in the Championship, and Burnley offered Heaton a two-year contract attaching him to the club until June 2015, with an option of a third year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22569957 |title=Burnley: Bristol City keeper Tom Heaton to join Clarets |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 May 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> A target of manager [[Sean Dyche]] while at Watford, Dyche's first Burnley signing was described as a "good technician" with a "great pedigree".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/dyche-delight-at-heaton-signing-170513-826442.aspx |title=Dyche delight at Heaton signing |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=17 May 2013}}</ref> Heaton immediately became first-choice goalkeeper for Burnley following the departures of [[Lee Grant (footballer, born 1983)|Lee Grant]] and [[Brian Jensen (footballer, born 1975)|Brian Jensen]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He made his Burnley debut against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 3 August 2013.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} On 24 August, he was the recipient of a rare technical caution (his second of the match) for handling the ball after releasing it whilst playing against Brighton, a match they lost 2–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23736888 |title=Brighton 2–0 Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Heaton was a part of Burnley's defence that allowed only 37 goals, the fewest in the league, as Burnley returned to the [[Premier League]] for the first time since 2009–10.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Heaton also picked up 19 clean sheets, the most by any keeper in the regular season.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
Heaton made his Premier League debut on 18 August against Chelsea in a 1–3 loss.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/18/burnley-chelsea-premier-league-match-report |title=Cesc Fábregas inspires Chelsea to opening Premier League win at Burnley |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |date=18 August 2014}}</ref> Heaton played in every minute of Burnley's Premier League campaign, the only goalkeeper in the league to do so,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/stats/top/players/mins_played |title=Premier League Player Stats - Minutes Played |work=Premier League |accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> but his efforts would not be enough, as Burnley and their league-worst offense were relegated at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/league-tables/premier-league/19-may-2015/|title=Premier League table after close of play on 19 May 2015|website=11v11.com|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> After the season, Heaton was voted by his teammates as Burnley's Players' Player of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2015/may/clarets-player-of-the-year-awards-2015/ |title=Clarets Player of the Year awards 2015 |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=25 May 2015 |accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Arsenal Vs Burnley (24108379784).jpg|thumb|upright|Heaton (right) playing for Burnley in 2016]]
On 30 June 2015, Heaton signed a new three-year deal at the club through to the summer of 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Heaton signs new Clarets contract |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/heaton-signs-new-clarets-contract-2514570.aspx |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=30 June 2015}}</ref> Taking over for [[Jason Shackell]], Heaton was named as captain for the [[2015–16 Burnley F.C. season|2015–16 season]], captaining the team for the first time on 8 August 2015, on the opening day of the [[2015–16 Football League Championship|2015–16 Championship season]] against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news |title=United in opening day draw |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/tur6eygqn5lg1prmxswgkfmmd/title/united-in-opening-day-draw |publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=8 August 2015 |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> Heaton kept 20 clean sheets during the season, second only to [[Dimitrios Konstantopoulos]] of [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxsports.com/soccer/stats?competition=23&season=20150&category=GOALKEEPING&pos=0&team=0&sort=7&sortOrder=0|title=2015-16 English Championship Statistics and Leaders: Goalkeeping|website=foxsports.com|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> as Burnley did not lose in the second half of the Championship season on their way to becoming champions and earning promotion back to the [[2016–17 Premier League|Premier League]] at their first attempt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=435&teamTabs=results|title=Burnley Results|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36176219|title=Charlton 0–3 Burnley|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 May 2016|accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref> Towards the end of the season, Heaton was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 7|Championship PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name=pfateam1516>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36106596 |title=PFA awards: Leicester and Spurs dominate Premier League team |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2016 |accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
On 20 July 2016, Heaton signed another new contract, this time a four-year deal running until the summer of 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/2016-17/skipper-heaton-signs-new-four-year-deal-3195783.aspx |title=Skipper Heaton signs new four-year deal |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=20 July 2016}}</ref> On 29 October, Heaton made numerous saves during the match against former club Manchester United, the highlight being a mid-air, fully extended save of [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]] that Heaton claimed "nearly broke [his] arm".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccer.nbcsports.com/2016/10/29/nearly-broke-my-arm-heaton-on-stunning-zlatan-save-day/ |title="Nearly broke my arm" – Heaton on stunning Zlatan save, day |publisher=NBC Sports |first=Nicholas |last=Mendola |date=29 October 2016}}</ref> Afterwards, Heaton required medical attention but remained in the match to lead Burnley to a 0–0 draw, being named Man of the Match in the process.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37737710 |title=Manchester United 0–0 Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 October 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> In the same season on 22 January 2017, Heaton made his 150th league appearance for the club as he was beaten by a 97th-minute penalty from [[Alexis Sánchez]] that saw Arsenal win 2–1.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/premier-league/2016-2017/live-arsenal-burnley_mtc862208/live.shtml|title=LIVE Arsenal - Burnley - Premier League - 22 January 2017|date=22 January 2017|work=Eurosport|access-date=21 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://us.soccerway.com/matches/2017/01/22/england/premier-league/arsenal-fc/burnley-fc/2241970/?ICID=PL_MS_09|title=Arsenal vs. Burnley - 22 January 2017 - Soccerway|website=us.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=21 March 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Having played for England at various youth levels, Heaton was handed his [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] debut in March 2008 by manager [[Stuart Pearce]] when he replaced [[Joe Hart]] as a substitute during a match against [[Poland national under-21 football team|Poland]].<ref>[http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/footballnation/cardiff-city-fc/2008/06/13/city-new-boy-wants-to-be-number-one-with-united-91466-21067081/ "City new boy wants to be number one with United"]. ''South Wales Echo''. Cardiff. Retrieved 13 June 2008.{{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref> However, he did not make the final squad for the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
On 21 May 2015, Heaton was called up to the [[England national football team|England senior team]] for the first time ahead of a friendly against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=England: Jamie Vardy, Charlie Austin & Tom Heaton in squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32823264 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Heaton continued to be included in [[Roy Hodgson]]'s squads before finally making his debut as an 87th-minute substitute in place of [[Fraser Forster]] in England's Euro 2016 warm-up match against [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]], played at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]'s [[Stadium of Light]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Tyrone |last=Marshall |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/14522372.Burnley_captain_Tom_Heaton_makes_his_England_debut/ |title=Burnley captain Tom Heaton makes his England debut |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=27 May 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
On 16 May 2018, he was one of 5 players named on standby for the 23-man [[England national football team|England national team]] squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>

Cork''' (born 25 June 1989) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|Burnley}} club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. He played for the [[Great Britain Olympic football team|Great Britain Olympic team]] at the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Summer Olympics]].
Cork started off his career with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] but between 2006 and 2011, he went on loan to a number of clubs, including [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] where he was named player of the year. Without making an appearance for Chelsea, he signed permanently to Championship club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2011 where he made over 100 appearances for them and helped them promoted to the Premier League by featuring in all their matches. Cork spent two and a half years with Premier League club [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] from January 2015 to July 2017 before his permanent move to Burnley where he featured in every match en route of the club qualifying to the [[UEFA Europa League]].
Cork has featured for [[England national football team|England]] from U16 in 2005 to U21 between 2008 and 2011, the Great Britain Olympic team and once for the senior national team.
==Early life== Cork was born in [[Carshalton]], London.<ref>{{Hugman|22656|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> He is the son of former footballer and manager [[Alan Cork]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/365527/Southampton-star-Jack-Cork-wants-Saints-to-win-the-FA-Cup |title=Southampton star Jack Cork wants Saints to win the FA Cup |first=Alex |last=Crook |newspaper=Daily Star |location=London |date=15 February 2014 |accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref>
==Career== ===Chelsea=== Cork joined the [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] youth system up age of nine, and captained both the club's youth and reserve teams.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/TeamPlyrsBios/PlayersC/BioCorkJFP.html |title=England Football Online |date=14 May 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> During the [[2006–07 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2006–07 season]], Cork twice went on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]].<ref name=sb0607/> Cork was selected to go on Chelsea's pre-season tour of the United States in summer 2007. He made his first appearance for the first team against [[Club América]] on 14 July. He played out-of-position at left back for most of the tour.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1073236 |title=Minute Detail: Chelsea 2 Club America 1 |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607021059/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1073236 |archivedate=7 June 2014}}</ref>
Cork spent the [[2007–08 Scunthorpe United F.C. season|2007–08 season]] on loan at newly promoted [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]]. His first league goals came for Scunthorpe, both against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]; in a 1–1 away draw on 27 November 2007<ref name=sb0708/> and in a 2–1 home victory on 1 March 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title=Scunthorpe 2–1 Coventry |publisher=BBC Sport |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7260445.stm |date=1 March 2008 |accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref> After 35 appearances,<ref name=sb0708/> despite Scunthorpe's relegation from the Championship,<ref>{{cite web |title=Championship: 2007/08: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=143 |work=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> he was voted the club's Player of the Year.<ref name=ScunthorpePOTY>{{cite web |title=Vote for your Player of the Season 2016/17 |url=https://www.scunthorpe-united.co.uk/news/2017/march/vote-for-your-player-of-the-season-201617/ |publisher=Scunthorpe United F.C. |date=29 March 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>
On 21 August 2008, Cork joined Championship club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on loan until 1 January 2009.<ref>{{cite news |title=Saints bag Chelsea's Cork on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/southampton/7574599.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2008 |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> In January 2009, Cork joined Championship club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on loan until the end of the [[2008–09 Watford F.C. season|2008–09 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/4015385.Hornets_snap_up_England_Under-21_international_Cork/ |title=Watford sign Chelsea's Jack Cork on loan until end of season |accessdate=13 July 2018 |date=2 January 2009 |first=Frank |last=Smith}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Watford on 24 January 2009 in a 4–3 victory over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in the fourth round of the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7842804.stm |title=Watford 4–3 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 January 2009 |accessdate=1 September 2009}}</ref> Cork signed a new three-year contract with Chelsea on 21 August 2009 and immediately joined Championship club Coventry City on loan until the end of December 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/chelsea-kid-jack-cork-handed-3372410 |title=Chelsea kid Jack Cork handed new three-year deal |publisher=Mirror |date=6 September 2009 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/8218228.stm |title=Cork may extend stay at Coventry |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2009 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
On 1 February 2010, Cork joined Premier League club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on loan until the end of the [[2009–10 Burnley F.C. season|2009–10 season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley boss delighted with signing of Chelsea youngster |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/8491608.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 February 2010 |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> He made his first appearance for Burnley in a 3–0 defeat away to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on his Premier League debut.<ref name=sb0910/> He then played in a 5–2 defeat against Aston Villa on 21 February 2010 and assisted Burnley's second goal.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bevan |first=Chris |title=Aston Villa 5–2 Burnley |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8518684.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=20 June 2011 |date=21 February 2010}}</ref> Cork scored his first goal for Burnley on 9 May 2010 in a 4–2 home win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], with a diving header to score Burnley's second to turn over a two-goal lead.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8656546.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 4–2 Tottenham |accessdate=20 June 2011 |date=9 May 2010}}</ref> His father revealed the day before in a local newspaper, the ''[[Lancashire Telegraph]]'', that Cork was looking to leave Chelsea in the summer and was willing to drop down into the Championship in order to do so.<ref>{{cite news |last=Flanagan |first=Chris |title=Burnley midfielder Cork is ready to leave Chelsea, says father |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/8154302.Burnley_midfielder_Cork_is_ready_to_leave_Chelsea__says_father/?ref=rss |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=8 May 2010 |accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref>
On 8 August 2010, Chelsea said that they would allow Cork to leave the club and were looking for offers of around £2 million.<ref>{{cite web |last=Scholes |first=Tony |title=Cork can go say Chelsea |url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/cork_can_go_say_chelsea_544341/index.shtml |work=Clarets Mad |publisher=Digital Sports Group |date=8 August 2010 |accessdate=20 June 2011}}</ref> On 12 August, Cork re-joined Burnley on loan for the [[2010–11 Burnley F.C. season|2010–11 season]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Loan star Jack's the Lad – Again! |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2119751,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927082801/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2119751%2C00.html |archivedate=27 September 2012 |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=12 August 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Cork scored a last minute winner at home to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 27 November, taking Burnley into the play-off positions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9220843.stm |title=Burnley 2–1 Derby |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 November 2010 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
===Southampton=== [[File:Jack Cork v Villa.jpg|thumb|upright|Cork playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2013]]
On 7 July 2011, Cork signed for newly promoted Championship club Southampton, after they agreed an undisclosed fee with Chelsea.<ref>{{cite web |title=Saints sign Jack Cork |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2388516,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907120400/http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10280~2388516%2C00.html |archivedate=7 September 2011 |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=7 July 2011 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Cork ended the [[2011–12 Southampton F.C. season|2011–12 season]] as the only Southampton player who appeared in every league match,<ref name=sb1112/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2471&teamTabs=stats |title=Southampton FC Player Appearances |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref> as the club earned promotion to the [[Premier League]] as runners-up in the Championship.<ref name=1112table>{{cite web |title=Championship: 2011/12: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=940 |work=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>
Cork missed Southampton's opening fixtures of the [[2012–13 Premier League]], due to an ankle injury, sustained against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in a friendly and a League Cup victory over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19181547 |title=Southampton midfielder Jack Cork out for up to six weeks |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2012 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> On 26 August 2014, he scored his first goal for Southampton in a 2–0 away victory over [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in the second round of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Millwall 0–2 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28847807 |accessdate=26 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 August 2014}}</ref>
He scored his first league goal for the club in a 4–0 home win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 13 September 2014<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chowdhury |first1=Saj |title=Southampton 4–0 Newcastle |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29090536 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 October 2014 |date=13 September 2014}}</ref> and his second and final league goal for the club came in an 8–0 home win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 18 October.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Reddy |first1=Luke |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29580147 |title=Southampton 8–0 Sunderland |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 October 2014 |accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref>
===Swansea City=== Cork signed for Southampton's Premier League rivals [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 30 January 2015 on a three-and-a-half-year contract,<ref>{{cite news |title=Jack Cork: Swansea City finalise signing of Southampton midfielder |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31040534 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=31 January 2015 |date=30 January 2015}}</ref> for a fee "believed to be in the region of £3 million".<ref>{{cite news |title=Swansea complete £3m signing of Jack Cork from Southampton |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jan/30/swansea-jack-cork-transfer-southampton |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=31 January 2015 |date=30 January 2015}}</ref> On 25 April 2015, he scored his first goal for Swansea in a 3–2 away win over Newcastle United.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/watch/video/sports/football/9822603/cork-nets-first-swansea-goal |title=Cork nets first Swansea goal |date=26 April 2015 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
Over a year after his first goal for the club, on 1 May 2016, he scored his second, with a 20-yard curling shot in a 3–1 home victory over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/swansea-vs-liverpool/341544 |title=Swansea City 3–1 Liverpool |date=1 May 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> This victory helped secure Swansea's Premier League status for the [[2016–17 Swansea City A.F.C. season|2016–17 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36122791 |title=Swansea City 3–1 Liverpool |date=1 May 2017 |first=Dafydd |last=Pritchard |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>
===Burnley=== Cork signed for Premier League club Burnley on 11 July 2017 on a four-year contract, for fee reported to be in the region of £8 million, rising to £10 million with add-ons.<ref>{{cite web |title=Cork: It's Great To Be Back! |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2017/july/cork-its-great-to-be-back/ |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=11 July 2017 |date=11 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Pritchard |first1=Dafydd |title=Jack Cork: Burnley sign midfielder from Swansea City for about £10m |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40557497 |accessdate=11 July 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 July 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal on his return to Burnley in an [[EFL Cup]] tie against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 23 August 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40944670 |title=Blackburn Rovers 0–2 Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2017 |accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref> His first Premier League goal for Burnley came against his former club Swansea City in a 2–0 win on 18 November. That goal ended a run of 43 appearances without a goal for the player.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Matthew |first1=Henry |title=Burnley 2–0 Swansea City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41951922 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 April 2018 |date=18 November 2017}}</ref>
On 16 August 2018, he scored the winning goal in Burnley's 1–0 victory over [[İstanbul Başakşehir F.K.|Istanbul Basaksehir]] in the Europa League qualifiers.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Emons |first1=Michael |title=Burnley 1–0 Istanbul Basaksehir |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45168370 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 August 2018 |date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== ===England=== Cork has represented England at many youth levels, making his [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] debut against the [[Czech Republic national under-19 football team|Czech Republic]] in May 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U19s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/05/U19sEliteRound_CzechReport.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20071029052657/http://www.thefa.com/England/U19s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/05/U19sEliteRound_CzechReport.htm |deadurl=yes |archivedate=29 October 2007 |title=Lions grab consolation |publisher=The Football Association}}</ref> He captained the England U19 squad to make the [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]], and was part of the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] squad at the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/5022592.Burnley_on-loan_star_Cork_earns_England_U21_selection/ |title=Burnley on-loan star Cork earns England U21 selection |publisher=Lancashire Telegraph |date=23 February 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
On 7 November 2017, Cork was called into the [[England national football team|England]] squad for friendly matches against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Jack Cork: Burnley midfielder called up to England squad after trio withdraw |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41899819 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=7 November 2017 |date=7 November 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 10 November 2017 as an 86th-minute substitute in a 0–0 draw against Germany at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil {{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = James Tarkowski | image = James Tarkowski (Oct 2017).jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Tarkowski playing for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in 2017 | fullname = James Alan Tarkowski<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|11|19|df=y}}<ref name=Hugman>{{Hugman|25491|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Manchester]], England | height = {{convert|1.85|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/teams/first-team/defender/james-tarkowski/ |title=James Tarkowski |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | currentclub = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | clubnumber = 5 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] | youthyears2 = 2009–2011 | youthclubs2 = [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] | years1 = | clubs1 = [[Maine Road F.C.|Maine Road]] | years2 = 2011–2014 | clubs2 = [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] | caps2 = 72 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2014–2016 | clubs3 = [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] | caps3 = 70 | goals3 = 4 | years4 = 2016– | clubs4 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps4 = 79 | goals4 = 3 | nationalyears1 = 2018– | nationalteam1 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 21:21, 27 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 10:56, 9 December 2018 (UTC) }} '''James Alan Tarkowski''' (born 19 November 1992) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre back]] for {{English football updater|Burnley}} club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
He began his professional career at [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] of [[EFL League One|League One]], where he made 89 appearances across all competitions. In January 2014, he moved to [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] for an undisclosed fee, winning promotion to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] in his first season. Two years later he signed for Burnley. He made his debut for England in March 2018, starting in a 1–1 draw against Italy.
==Early and personal life== Tarkowski was born in [[Manchester]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/james-tarkowski-237102/ |title=James Tarkowski |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref> and grew up in [[New Moston]].<ref name=grounded>{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Keegan |title=Tarkowski staying grounded despite United links |url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/oldham-defender-james-tarkowski-coy-6207277 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=18 October 2013 |accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> He attended New Moston Primary School and [[Failsworth School|Failsworth High School]], which he left in 2009.<ref name=grounded/>
Tarkowski began his career in the youth system at [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], before being released at the age of 14 at his own request. After his spell at Blackburn, Tarkowski had a stint playing senior football at [[Maine Road F.C.|Maine Road]] in the [[North West Counties Football League|North West Counties League]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4974926/Burnley-s-James-Tarkowski-no-prima-donna.html|title=Burnley's James Tarkowski is no prima donna - he's into budget holidays and packed lunches: 'I've stayed in some rascal hostels, £2-a-night places!'|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=12 October 2017|accessdate=18 September 2018}}</ref>
He is a Manchester United fan and admired [[David Beckham]] and [[Paul Scholes]] while growing up.<ref name="Crewe 0–2 Oldham" />
==Club career== ===Oldham Athletic=== ====Early years==== Tarkowski joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on a two-year scholarship in May 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jan/04/oldham-james-tarkowski-liverpool-luis-suarez-fa-cup|title=Oldham's young James Tarkowski out to muzzle Liverpool's Luis Suárez|author=Wilson, Paul|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Young hopefuls sign up |url=http://www.oldham-chronicle.co.uk/news-features/10/oldham-athletic/24247/young-hopefuls-sign-up |newspaper=Oldham Chronicle |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=22 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202123132/http://www.oldham-chronicle.co.uk/news-features/10/oldham-athletic/24247/young-hopefuls-sign-up |archivedate=2 February 2014 }}</ref> He made his reserve-team debut in October 2009. A [[centre back]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oldhamathletic.co.uk/team/player-profile/index.aspx?playerid=460961 |title=Oldham Athletic AFC Player Profiles |publisher=Oldham Athletic A.F.C. |date=6 July 2013 |accessdate=21 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202225154/http://www.oldhamathletic.co.uk/team/player-profile/index.aspx?playerid=460961 |archivedate=2 February 2014 }}</ref> Tarkowski was called up to the first team for the first time for a league match versus [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] on 15 January 2011.<ref>{{cite web |title=Scholars win first team calls |url=http://www.oldhamathletic.co.uk/page/NewsUpdate/0,,10337~2266393,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110116104610/http://www.oldhamathletic.co.uk/page/NewsUpdate/0%2C%2C10337~2266393%2C00.html |archivedate=16 January 2011 |publisher=Oldham Athletic A.F.C. |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=22 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> His senior debut came on 22 January, coming on as an 80th-minute substitute for the injured [[Neal Trotman]] in a 2–1 home win over [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Oldham 2–1 Brentford |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9362041.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=22 January 2011 }}</ref> Tarkowski made his first Latics start in a 1–0 defeat to [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on 12 March and played the full 90 minutes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/155226/james-tarkowski?season=2010|title=James Tarkowski |website=ESPN FC |accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref> He was awarded a two-year professional contract by the club in May 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oldhamathletic-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/tarkowski_signs__pro_deal_679577/index.shtml |title=Tarkowski signs pro deal |website=Latics Mad |publisher=Digital Sports Group |date=28 May 2011 |accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> He made 9 appearances during the second half of the [[2010–11 Oldham Athletic A.F.C. season|2010–11 season]].<ref name=sb1011/>
Tarkowski had to wait until 10 December 2011 to make his first appearance of the [[2011–12 Oldham Athletic A.F.C. season|2011–12 season]],<ref name=espn>{{cite web|url = http://www.espnfc.com/player/155226/james-tarkowski?season=2011|title = James Tarkowski|publisher=ESPN FC |accessdate = 17 August 2015}}</ref> when he came on as a 61st-minute substitute for [[Jean-Yves Mvoto]] in a 2–0 home defeat to [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16015587 |title=Oldham 0–2 Sheffield Wed |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 December 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> A half time substitute appearance in Oldham's 2–1 [[Football League Trophy]] Northern Area final first leg defeat to [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] on 30 January 2012 kicked off a run which saw Tarkowski included in almost all of Oldham's first-team squads until the end of the season.<ref name=espn /> Tarkowski crowned his run of appearances by scoring his first senior goal for the club on the final day of the season in a 2–1 win over [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]].<ref name="firstoldhamgoal">{{cite news |title=Oldham 2–1 Carlisle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17878476|accessdate=5 May 2012|publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2012}}</ref> He made 18 appearances during the 2011–12 season and scored one goal.<ref name=sb1112/>
====Breakthrough==== [[File:James Tarkowski 21-07-2012 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Tarkowski playing for [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] in 2012]]
Tarkowski began the [[2012–13 Oldham Athletic A.F.C. season|2012–13 season]] as a first-choice centre back alongside Jean-Yves Mvoto and started Oldham's first six games of the season.<ref name=sb1213/> He scored his first goal of the season in a 2–0 league win over [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] on 2 October 2012.<ref name="Crewe 0–2 Oldham">{{cite news |last=Scott |first=Ged |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19709768 |title=Crewe Alexandra 0–2 Oldham Athletic |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Tarkowski played a part in Oldham's run to the fifth round of the [[FA Cup]], playing in the first round win over [[Conference Premier]] team [[Kidderminster Harriers F.C.|Kidderminster Harriers]] and starting in the home draw and away replay defeat to [[Premier League]] team [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in the fifth round.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/155226/james-tarkowski?season=2012|title=James Tarkowski|publisher=ESPN FC|accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref> He scored his second goal of the season in a 2–1 league win over [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]] on 19 February 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21448791 |title=Stevenage 1–2 Oldham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 February 2013 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Tarkowski made 26 appearances and scored two goals during the 2012–13 season.<ref name=sb1213/> He signed a new two-year contract in the summer of 2013.<ref>{{cite news | title = Tarkowski Signs New Contract | url = http://www.oldhamathletic.co.uk/news/article/20130613-tarkowski-863934.aspx | publisher = Oldham Athletic A.F.C. | date = 13 June 2013 | accessdate = 13 June 2013}}</ref>
Tarkowski began the [[2013–14 Oldham Athletic A.F.C. season|2013–14 season]] with a bang, scoring Oldham's first goal in a 4–3 away league win over Stevenage on the opening day.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23474975 |title=Stevenage 3–4 Oldham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 August 2013 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> He was picked by the Latics supporters as Oldham's Player of the Month for August 2013.<ref name=oldham2292013>{{cite web|url=http://www.oldhamathletic.co.uk/news/article/20130922-potm-1069654.aspx |title=Tarkowski wins award |publisher=Oldham Athletic A.F.C. |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Now lining up at centre back alongside [[Jonathan Grounds]],<ref name=grounded/> Tarkowski scored his second goal in a 2–1 defeat to [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] on 9 September 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23925593 |title=Preston 2–1 Oldham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 September 2013 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Tarkowski was an ever-present in Oldham's runs to the Northern Area semi-final of the Football League Trophy and the third round of the FA Cup.<ref name=sb1314/> He started the FA Cup third round tie against Premier League team [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] and scored an 82nd minute [[own goal]], which consigned the Latics to a 2–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite news |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25539775 |title=Liverpool 2–0 Oldham Athletic |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Tarkowski's form saw him offered a new contract extending until the end of the 2016–17 season on 22 January 2014,<ref>{{cite news | title = Oldham: James Tarkowski offered new Latics deal | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25846815 | publisher = BBC Sport | accessdate = 22 January 2014}}</ref> but he departed [[Boundary Park]] 9 days later.<ref name=Brentford31114>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/james-tarkowski-31.01.14-1330159.aspx |title=Brentford Sign James Tarkowski |publisher=Brentford F.C. |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> During his time with the Latics, Tarkowski made 89 appearances and scored six goals.<ref name=soccerbase/>
===Brentford=== Tarkowski signed for League One club Brentford on a three-and-a-half-year contract for an undisclosed fee on 31 January 2014.<ref name=Brentford31114/> After a period on the bench, he made his Brentford debut with a start in a 0–0 draw away to Carlisle United on 1 March.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26301913 |title=Carlisle United 0–0 Brentford |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2014 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club on his third appearance, heading in to send the Bees on their way to a 2–0 victory over [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] on 11 March.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26428674 |title=Brentford 2–0 Tranmere Rovers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 March 2014 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Four days later, Tarkowski was [[Red card (football)|sent off]] for the second time in his career during a 1–0 win over Leyton Orient.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26492931 |title=Leyton Orient 0–1 Brentford |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 March 2014 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Following Brentford's promotion to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] on 18 April, Tarkowski scored his second goal for the club in a 2–2 draw at [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] on 21 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27016685 |title=Milton Keynes Dons 2–2 Brentford |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 August 2013 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> He finished the [[2013–14 Brentford F.C. season|2013–14 season]] with 13 appearances and two goals.<ref name=sb1314/>
Tarkowski began his first season at Championship level as an ever-present in the Bees' league matches.<ref name=sb1415/> He suffered a dip in form in September and early October, stepping up to take his first [[Penalty (association football)|penalty]] for the club in a league match versus [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on 27 September and hammering the ball over the bar.<ref name=":7">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29289510|title=Brentford 2–0 Leeds United|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> He was spared his blushes, with [[Jota (footballer)|Jota]] and [[Alan McCormack]] on target in the eventual 2–0 win.<ref name=":7" /> Tarkowski gave away a penalty in a 2–1 defeat to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 30 September and received his fourth [[Yellow card (association football)|yellow card]] of the season (his third in four matches).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29320618|title=Watford 2–1 Brentford|author=Osborne, Chris|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> Another yellow card in a 0–0 draw with [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on 18 October saw him incur a suspension and he failed to appear again until 28 December,<ref name=sb1415/> scoring what proved to be [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]' winner with an own goal in a 2–1 defeat.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30566334|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 2–1 Brentford|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> Despite the blunder, Tarkowski held onto his starting place and scored his first goal of the season against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 25 April 2015, making sure of the points with the second in a 2–0 win.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/155226/james-tarkowski?season=2014|title=James Tarkowski|publisher=ESPN FC |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> Tarkowski had the opportunity to convert a late penalty to make it two goals in two games in the following match against Wigan Athletic, but his miss made little difference with the Bees already 3–0 ahead.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32460049|title=Brentford 3–0 Wigan Athletic|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> He appeared in both legs of Brentford's 5–1 [[2015 Football League play-offs#Championship|playoff semi-final]] aggregate defeat to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] and finished the [[2014–15 Brentford F.C. season|2014–15]] season with 38 appearances and one goal.<ref name=sb1415/>
Tarkowski helped salvage a 2–2 draw with [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] on the opening day of the [[2015–16 Brentford F.C. season|2015–16]] season, [[Assist (football)|feeding]] [[Andre Gray]] to score in [[injury time]],<ref>{{cite news|title = Brentford 2–2 Ipswich Town|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33744133|publisher = BBC Sport |accessdate = 9 August 2015}}</ref> before bundling home a 96th-minute equaliser to earn a place in the [[English Football League|Football League]] Team of the Week.<ref>{{cite web|title = Sky Bet Football League Team of the Week|url = http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/2015/sky-bet-football-league-team-of-the-week-2607652.aspx|publisher = The Football League|accessdate = 10 August 2015|first = Alex|last = Butcher}}</ref> He suffered a [[Displacement (orthopedic surgery)|displaced fracture]] of the nose in the following match versus [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]],<ref>{{cite web|title = Brentford FC Injury update|url = http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/brentford-fc-injury-update-18.08.15-2629059.aspx|publisher=Brentford F.C. |accessdate = 27 September 2015|first = Brentford|last = FC}}</ref> but kept his place alongside Harlee Dean until suffering a calf injury in a 1–1 draw with Leeds United on 12 September.<ref>{{cite web|title = September injury update|url = http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/september-injury-update-23.09.15-2705230.aspx|publisher=Brentford F.C. |accessdate = 27 September 2015|first = Brentford|last = FC}}</ref> He missed two matches before being [[Red card (association football)|sent off]] on his return in a 2–1 defeat to Sheffield Wednesday.<ref>{{cite news |title = Brentford 1–2 Sheffield Wednesday|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34300233|publisher = BBC Sport |accessdate = 27 September 2015}}</ref> Amidst a number of transfer bids,<ref>{{Cite news|title = Brentford's James Tarkowski refuses to play in match against Burnley|url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jan/15/brentford-james-tarkowski-burnley-championship|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 15 January 2016|accessdate = 25 January 2016|issn = 0261-3077 |agency=Press Association}}</ref> Tarkowski was internally disciplined for refusing to play in Brentford's match versus [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 15 January 2016,<ref>{{cite web|title = Club statement: James Tarkowski|url = http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/club-statement-james-tarkowski-15.01.16-2903724.aspx|publisher=Brentford F.C. |accessdate = 15 January 2016}}</ref> for which he later apologised.<ref>{{cite web|title = James Tarkowski issues personal statement|url = http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/james-tarkowki-issues-personal-statement-25.01.16-2920320.aspx#l2Ohe2lhYXp4tpuF.99|publisher=Brentford F.C. |accessdate = 25 January 2016}}</ref> He failed to appear for the Bees again and departed [[Griffin Park]] two weeks later, having made 74 appearances and scored four goals in two years with the club.<ref name="soccerbase">{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=58187 |title=5 James Tarkowski |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref>
===Burnley=== [[File:James Tarkowski TomHeaton.jpg|thumb|upright|Tarkowski (centre) playing for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in 2017]]
On 1 February 2016, Tarkowski signed a three-and-a-half-year contract with Championship club Burnley for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Clarets Sign James Tarkowski |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/clarets-sign-james-tarkowski-2932970.aspx |publisher=Burnley FC |date=1 February 2016 |accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref> Tarkowski made his club debut on 20 February against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]], entering as a substitute in the first half for [[Michael Keane (footballer, born 1993)|Michael Keane]], who was forced off with a head injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/14293941.Defender_James_Tarkowski_believes_there_s_more_to_come_from_Burnley_side/ |title=Defender James Tarkowski believes there's more to come from Burnley side |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |first=Suzanne |last=Geldard |date=22 February 2016}}</ref> Tarkowski deputised for Keane for the next two games, with Burnley victorious against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] and [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/news/14339170.Clarets_defender_Keane_praises_Tarkowski__but_is_happy_to_be_back_in_the_side/ |title=Clarets defender Keane praises Tarkowski, but is happy to be back in the side |newspaper=News Shopper |first=Suzanne |last=Geldard |date=12 March 2016}}</ref> However, Keane was preferred by manager [[Sean Dyche]] at right [[Defender (association football)|centre-back]] upon his return to fitness as Tarkowski was limited to one substitution appearance the rest of the season. In third position in the table at the time of Tarkowski's signing, Burnley went unbeaten the rest of the season as they won their third ever second-tier title and direct promotion to the [[2016–17 Premier League|Premier League]] on their first attempt.
Tarkowski was handed the [[Captain (association football)|captain's armband]] for Burnley's 1–0 extra-time defeat to fourth-tier [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] in the [[2016–17 EFL Cup#Second round|EFL Cup]] on 24 August, after Dyche had made 10 changes to the team that upset Liverpool four days prior.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37103144 |title=Accrington Stanley 1–0 Burnley (AET) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2016}}</ref> Tarkowski made his Premier League debut on 27 August at [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], coming on as a substitute and receiving a booking for a foul in the run-up to Chelsea's final goal in the 3–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uptheclarets.com/no-answer-to-chelsea |title=No answer to Chelsea |website=UpTheClarets |first=Tony |last=Scholes |date=28 August 2016}}</ref> Unable to crack the preferred centre-back partnership of Keane and [[Ben Mee]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/15020080._It___s_not_been_easy____Burnley_defender_James_Tarkowski_admits_life_on_bench_can_be_tough/ |title='It's not been easy' – Burnley defender James Tarkowski admits life on bench can be tough |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |first=Tyrone |last=Marshall |date=12 January 2017}}</ref> Tarkowski received scant playing time, despite being an ever-present on the bench.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2017/april/tarkowski-no-loss-of-momentum/ |title=Tarkowski: No Loss Of Momentum |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=26 April 2017}}</ref> He was a halftime substitution on 23 April 2017 against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] for Mee, who left with a shin injury,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/club/burnley/379/blog/post/3110996/burnley-fall-to-deserved-defeat-vs-man-united-as-joey-barton-struggles |title=Burnley fall to deserved defeat vs Man United as Joey Barton struggles |publisher=ESPN FC |first=Jamie |last=Smith |date=23 April 2017}}</ref> opening the door for his first Premier League start on 29 April against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]. Tarkowski endured being hit by an object thrown by a Palace fan during celebrations of [[Ashley Barnes]]' opening goal, as well as keeping [[Christian Benteke]] in his back pocket en route to a clean sheet. Manager Dyche lauded his performance as "outstanding".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/15259045.Sean_Dyche_hails__outstanding__James_Tarkowski_as_battle_for_places_in_Burnley_side_hots_up/ |title=Sean Dyche hails 'outstanding' James Tarkowski as battle for places in Burnley side hots up |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |first=Tyrone |last=Marshall |date=3 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/club/burnley/379/blog/post/3118567/james-tarkowski-capable-of-filling-the-void-left-by-michael-keane-at-burnley |title=James Tarkowski capable of filling the void left by Michael Keane at Burnley |publisher=ESPN FC |first=Jamie |last=Smith |date=4 May 2017}}</ref> Tarkowski would retain his place in the team for Burnley's final four fixtures, during which Burnley ensured their participation in the [[2017–18 Premier League|next edition]].
During the summer transfer window, teammate Michael Keane departed for Everton, allowing Tarkowski to line up with Mee in the center of Burnley's defense on a full-time basis.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/burnley-not-planning-replace-michael-10992919 |title=Burnley not planning to replace Michael Keane – because they have a ready-made successor in the building |newspaper=Daily Mirror |first=David |last=Anderson |date=15 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11671/10935840/michael-keane-joins-everton-from-burnley |title=Michael Keane joins Everton from Burnley |publisher=Sky Sports |first=Dev |last=Trahan |date=4 July 2017}}</ref> Assigned the shirt number 26 initially, Tarkowski assumed the number 5 shirt vacated by Keane ahead of the season. Tarkowski's performance against Crystal Palace on 10 September was deemed Man of the Match worthy by [[Sky Sports]], as Tarkowski held Benteke and Palace without a goal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/15529718.Sean_Dyche_backs_defensive_work_of_James_Tarkowski_as_he_cements_Burnley_place/ |title=Sean Dyche backs defensive work of James Tarkowski as he cements Burnley place |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |first=Tyrone |last=Marshall |date=13 September 2017}}</ref> His 17 clearances in the match were the most by anyone in the Premier League that season, besting a mark previously held by himself in Burnley's surprise opening day victory over Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11708/11054419/is-defending-a-dying-art-burnleys-james-tarkowski-bucks-the-trend |title=Is defending a dying art? Burnley's James Tarkowski bucks the trend |publisher=Sky Sports |first=Adam |last=Bates |date=27 September 2017}}</ref>
==International career== Tarkowski was eligible to play for Poland through his grandfather but preferred to play for England, stating "I've always seen myself as an English person so to play for Poland would be difficult,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/11298525/england-new-boy-james-tarkowski-admits-playing-for-poland-would-have-been-difficult|title=England new-boy James Tarkowski admits playing for Poland would have been 'difficult'|first=|last=|date=20 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/football-notebook-burnley-star-holding-out-for-england-lgf9fkbjb |title=Football Notebook: Burnley star holding out for England |first=Matt |last=Hughes |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=16 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/former-bee-good-enough-play-13738531|title=Former Bee good enough to play for England – and we get more money if he does – says Brentford owner|first=Tim|last=Street|date=9 October 2017}}</ref> On 15 March 2018, he was named in the [[England national football team|England]] squad for pre-[[2018 FIFA World Cup]] friendlies against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] and [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in March.<ref>{{cite news |title=England call-ups for uncapped quartet as Jack Wilshere earns recall |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43344416 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 March 2018 |accessdate=15 March 2018}}</ref> He made his debut on 27 March when starting in the 1–1 draw with Italy at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 1–1 Italy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43466395 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 March 2018 |accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref>
On 16 May 2018, he was one of 5 players named on standby for [[Gareth Southgate]]'s 23-man [[England national football team|England national team]] squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref> but Tarkowski was reported to have withdrawn from the standby list later for hernia operation.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44275387 |title=Burnley defender James Tarkowski to leave England set-up for hernia operation |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 May 2018 |accessdate=27 May 2018}}</ref>
