Reserves and Academy|Manchester City]] | youthyears1 = 2006–2008 | years1 = 2008–2012 | clubs1 = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2011 | clubs2 = → [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] (loan) | caps2 = 15 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2011–2012 | clubs3 = → [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] (loan) | caps3 = 19 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2012– | clubs4 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps4 = 239 | goals4 = 6 | nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2009 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps2 = 5 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 2 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 21:20, 27 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Benjamin Thomas Mee''' (born 21 September 1989) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].
Starting off with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], Mee only made one [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] match for them before being loaned out to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and Burnley, joining the latter on a permanent basis. He has made over 200 appearances for them since then. He has also featured for the England youth teams from U19 to U21 level.
==Club career== ===Manchester City=== Mee was born in [[Sale, Greater Manchester|Sale]], Greater Manchester.<ref>{{Hugman|24539|accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> He first came to prominence for Manchester City as the captain of the City [[Manchester City F.C. Reserves and Academy#Academy|Academy]] squad which won the 2008 [[FA Youth Cup]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2297541/FA-Youth-Cup-Manchester-City-crush-Chelsea.html |title=FA Youth Cup: Manchester City crush Chelsea |date=17 April 2008 |accessdate=23 November 2010 |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Mee recalls Youth Cup win |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Academy-news/Archive/2009/March/Mee-recalls-Youth-Cup-win |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=6 March 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> He signed a two-year contract that would keep him at City until 2011.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mee signs new City contract |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Club-news/Archive/2009/February/Mee-signs-new-City-contract |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=3 March 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref>
Mee was given his first real test of first-team experience when he was taken on City's US tour in the summer of 2010, with club manager [[Roberto Mancini]] expressing that he wanted to blood his youth players and have a chance to see what they could do at a higher level than reserve fixtures. Mee made up two appearances, against [[Portland Timbers]] and [[New York Red Bulls]].<ref>{{cite news |title=US Tour: Red Bulls 2–1 City |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/American-Pre-season-tour/2010/July/US-Tour-City-v-Red-Bull |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=25 July 2010 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref>
After being given number 41 shirt,<ref>{{cite news |title=City squad numbers revealed |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/Archive/2010/July/Adebayor-snaps-up-No9-shirt |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=29 July 2010 |accessdate=20 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140901194615/http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/Archive/2010/July/Adebayor-snaps-up-No9-shirt |archivedate=1 September 2014 |df=dmy}}</ref> Mee followed up his tour appearances with a starting line-up appearance in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on 22 September 2010 in a 2–1 away loss.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/9010120.stm |title=West Brom – Manchester City |date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=22 September 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Alongside Mee making his debut, [[Javan Vidal]] and [[John Guidetti]] were given their first competitive appearances for the club in a match where three of the four players in the defensive line were young [[Manchester City F.C. Reserves and Academy#Elite Development Squad|Elite Development Squad]] players and a full six of the starting line-up were aged 21 or younger and had come through the club's academy system.
===Leicester City (loan)=== On [[New Years Day]] 2011, Mee joined former Manchester City manager [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]]'s [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] side on loan for the rest of the 2010–11 season.<ref name="Mee joins Foxes on loan">{{cite web |title=Mee joins Foxes on loan |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/EDS-news/2011/January/Mee-joins-Foxes-on-loan |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=1 January 2011 |accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref> After signing for the club, Mee would join his Manchester City's teammate [[Greg Cunningham]] at Leicester City.<ref>{{cite news |title=Foxes land City youngster |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/6629057/ |publisher=Sky Sports |date=1 January 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref> After two weeks yet playing them, Mee finally made his debut for Leicester City in a 4–2 win over [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City 4 – 2 Millwall |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10274~53356,00.html |publisher=LCFC.com |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617010808/http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10274~53356%2C00.html |archivedate=17 June 2010 |df=dmy}}</ref> On 12 March 2011, Mee provided his first professional assist for [[Miguel Vítor]] to score his first goal in the match against [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] which he scored twice later in the match which Leicester City won 3–0.<ref>{{cite news |title=Scunthorpe United 0 – 3 Leicester City |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10274~53162,00.html |publisher=LCFC.com |date=12 March 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315082422/http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10274~53162%2C00.html |archivedate=15 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 25 April 2011, Mee provided another his second assist for [[Jeffrey Bruma]] to score against Watford in a 4–2 win.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City 4 – 2 Watford |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10274~52462,00.html |publisher=LCFC.com |date=25 April 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904002934/http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10274~52462%2C00.html |archivedate=4 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
After the end of 2010–11 season, Mee returned to Manchester City after 6 months at Leicester City.<ref>{{cite news |title=eicester City's season finishing far too early for Ben Mee |url=http://leicestercityfootballclub.com/2011/05/06/leicester-citys-season-finishing-far-too-early-for-ben-mee/ |publisher=Leicester City Football Club.com |date=6 May 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref> Following the sacking of Sven Göran Eriksson, Mee commented that he was sad to hear of the news.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ben Mee sad to see Sven-Goran Eriksson go |url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/Ben-Mee-sad-Sven-Goran-Eriksson/story-13722180-detail/story.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120912011250/http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/Ben-Mee-sad-Sven-Goran-Eriksson/story-13722180-detail/story.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 September 2012 |work=Leicester Mercury |date=1 November 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref>
===Burnley=== [[File:Arsenal Vs Burnley (24440984920).jpg|thumb|right|Mee playing against Arsenal]] On 14 July 2011 it was confirmed that Mee had joined [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on a season long loan.<ref name="Mee loan">{{Cite web |url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/burnley_get_mee_685858/index.shtml |title=Burnley get Mee |work=clarets-mad.co.uk |publisher=Supporters of Burnley Football Club |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2392671,00.html |title=City Starlet Mee is First Summer Signing |work=burnleyfootballclub.com |publisher=Burnley Football Club |date=3 August 2011 |accessdate=29 October 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717022039/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2392671%2C00.html |archivedate=17 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Following his move to Burnley on loan, Mee hints that his good performance at Burnley could earn him a chance back at parent club Manchester City next year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mee keen to impress |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7219908/ |publisher=Sky Sports |date=3 October 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref>
On 19 July 2011, Mee made his debut for Burnley in a pre-season friendly match against before coming off for [[David Edgar (soccer)|David Edgar]] on the 67th minute in a 2–0 loss against League Two side [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Bristol Rovers 2 Burnley 0 |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2396860,00.html |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=29 July 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723010846/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2396860%2C00.html |archivedate=23 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 6 August 2011, Mee made his league debut for Burnley in a 2–2 draw against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] and played 90 minutes until the end of the match.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley 2 – 2 Watford |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10413~58431,00.html |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=6 August 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930012346/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10413~58431%2C00.html |archivedate=30 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 29 November 2011, Mee got his first clean sheet for Burnley without letting an opponent score, capping a perfect birthday for Burnley manager [[Eddie Howe]] in a 4–0 win over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley 4 – 0 Ipswich Town |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10413~58516,00.html |publisher=Burnley Football Club.com |date=29 November 2011 |accessdate=10 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310132510/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10413~58516%2C00.html |archivedate=10 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 10 January 2012, Burnley boss Eddie Howe expressed interest in signing Mee on a permanent basis with Manchester City sanctioning a sale just days after signing former Manchester City teammate [[Kieran Trippier]] who was also on loan at the club. Mee joined on a permanent three and a half-year deal on 17 January for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley sign Ben Mee from Manchester City permanently |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16483336.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 January 2012 |accessdate=17 January 2012}}</ref> His move to Burnley has comes as no surprise to find that the club have moved to bring him on board full-time.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mee makes permanent move |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7439333/ |publisher=Sky Sports |date=17 January 2012 |accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref> During a match against Reading in a 1–0 loss on 27 February 2012, Mee made an impressive tremendous clearance by using his head to block a [[Noel Hunt]] shot to prevent Reading scoring for a second time.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley defender Mee blocks shot with his head |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17103211 |publisher=BBC (British Broadcasting Corporation) |date=27 February 2012 |accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref> However, his season ended after suffering a slight back fracture which he sustained during a 5–1 win over [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Clarets defender Mee could miss rest of season |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/9636129.Clarets_defender_Mee_could_miss_rest_of_season/ |work=Lancashire Telegraph |date=5 April 2012 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> In combination of his loan spell and permanent spell at Burnley, Mee finished his season, making thirty-one appearances.
In the [[2012–13 Burnley F.C. season|2012–13 season]], Mee started his season when he appeared sporadic at the start until he scored his first goal for the club, in a 2–2 draw against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on 28 September 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley 2–2 Millwall |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19684195 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 September 2012 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> However soon after, Mee suffered a knee injury during the [[East Lancashire derby|Lancashire derby]], which kept him out for several weeks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-in-injury-setback-041212-525501.aspx |title=Mee in Injury Setback |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=20 August 2014 |date=4 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820220054/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-in-injury-setback-041212-525501.aspx |archivedate=20 August 2014 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> Mee made his return from injury, on 11 March 2013, as Burnley and [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] both drew 1–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/fixtures-results/match-report/?matchid=3594562&tcmuri=183735 |title=Burnley 0 – 1 Hull City |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=20 August 2014 |date=11 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820220728/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/fixtures-results/match-report/?matchid=3594562&tcmuri=183735 |archivedate=20 August 2014 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> In the next match, on 17 March 2013, Mee was sent-off after a second bookable offense when Burnley meet Blackburn Rovers meet again, as they both drew 1–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackburn Rovers 1–1 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21732287 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 March 2013 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> Soon after that, Mee continued to be sidelined with injuries, including missing out for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/defensive-duo-still-sidelined-040413-753037.aspx |title=Defensive Duo Still Sidelined |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=20 August 2014 |date=4 April 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820220815/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/defensive-duo-still-sidelined-040413-753037.aspx |archivedate=20 August 2014 |dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/dyche-opportunity-knocks-180413-780229.aspx |title=Dyche: Opportunity Knocks |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=20 August 2014 |date=18 April 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820220822/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/dyche-opportunity-knocks-180413-780229.aspx |archivedate=20 August 2014 |dead-url=yes}}</ref>
In the [[2013–14 Burnley F.C. season|2013–14 season]], Mee sustained a knee injury in the pre-season friendly and made a return, though he missed the first four matches, due to being on the bench.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-a-doubt-for-season-opener-230713-939776.aspx |title=Mee A Doubt For Season Opener |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=20 August 2014 |date=23 July 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820221829/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-a-doubt-for-season-opener-230713-939776.aspx |archivedate=20 August 2014 |dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-returns-to-action-070813-977079.aspx |title=Mee Returns To Action |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=20 August 2014 |date=7 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820221832/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-returns-to-action-070813-977079.aspx |archivedate=20 August 2014 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> From late-December to January, Mee had been absent twice in weeks. Despite the absent, Mee played a vital role as a left-back position, where he helped the club get promoted to Premier League and made thirty-eight appearances.
In the [[2014–15 Burnley F.C. season|2014–15 season]], Mee started his season well when he signed a three-year contract that will keep him until 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-signs-three-year-deal-300714-1792810.aspx |title=Turf Moor Is The Place For Mee |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=20 August 2014 |date=30 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820222838/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/mee-signs-three-year-deal-300714-1792810.aspx |archivedate=20 August 2014 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> Mee made his Premier League in the opening match of the season as a left-back, as Burnley lost 3–1 to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley 1–3 Chelsea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28735901 |accessdate=18 August 2014 |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=20 August 2014}}</ref> Mee scored the late equaliser for Burnley in [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] against Chelsea to keep the final score 1–1 and his goal was the second goal of the season Chelsea conceded from a corner kick.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31466726 |title=Chelsea 1–1 Burnley |date=21 February 2015 |publisher=BBC}}</ref>
==International career== At international level, Mee has represented England at [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] level, making his debut as a substitute in a friendly against [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2010/GermanyvEngland/EnglandMatchReport?p=mr&mid=115512 |title=Germany v England |date=16 November 2010 |accessdate=23 November 2010 |publisher=the FA}}</ref>

'''Jóhann Berg Guðmundsson''' (born 27 October 1990) is an Icelandic professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Left winger|winger]] for {{English football updater|Burnley}} club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[Iceland national football team|Iceland national team]].
Jóhann began his senior career at [[Breiðablik UBK|Breiðablik]] for a single season before moving to Dutch team [[AZ Alkmaar]] in the [[Eredivisie]] where they also participated in the [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]]. After a few seasons with them, he joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] for two seasons, then to newly promoted club Burnley where he featured for most of the [[2017–18 Burnley F.C. season|2017–18 season]] in qualifying for the Europa League.
Jóhann was part of the Iceland national team in both the [[UEFA Euro 2016]] and [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], the former competition saw him assisting Iceland's first ever goal in a major tournament.
==Club career== ===Breiðablik 2008–09=== Born in [[Reykjavík]], Jóhann started his career at [[Breiðablik UBK|Breiðablik]], but moved to England early in his career when his parent decided to relocate there. He had spells with the youth team at [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], while studying at the International School of London. After failing to adapt to life in London, he decided to move back to Iceland in 2008, joining his boyhood club [[Breiðablik UBK|Breiðablik]] as he admitted missing playing football and attending school with his friends.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fotbolti.net/fullStory.php?id=61651|title=Jóhann Berg: Frá Chelsea og Fulham í byrjunarlið Breiðabliks|website=Fotbolti.net|language=Icelandic|date=20 May 2008|accessdate=19 July 2016}}</ref>
After returning to Breiðablik, Jóhann made his senior debut in the opening match of the season, where he played 72 minutes, in a 1–1 draw against [[Íþróttabandalag Akraness]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Leystum sterka vörn ÍA ágætlega|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/efstadeild/2008/05/10/leystum_sterka_vorn_ia_agaetlega/|publisher=mbl.is|language=Icelandic|date=10 May 2008|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> He established himself as first team regular in the [[2008 Úrvalsdeild]], where he played often as left wing and striker,<ref name="GuðmundssonMBL.is">{{cite news|title=Jóhann Berg fremstur jafningja|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/efstadeild/2008/08/11/johann_berg_fremstur_jafningja/|publisher=mbl.is|language=Icelandic|date=11 August 2008|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> and scored his first Breiðablik goal on 7 July 2008, in a 2–0 win over [[Fylkir]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Blikar unnu þreytulega Fylkismenn|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/efstadeild/2008/07/07/blikar_unnu_threytulega_fylkismenn/|publisher=mbl.is|language=Icelandic|date=7 July 2008|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> Jóhann finished the season with 22 appearances, six goals, and was voted best player for the second third of the Icelandic Premier League season.<ref name="GuðmundssonMBL.is" />
===AZ Alkmaar 2009–14=== [[File:Johann-berg-gudmondsson-1313350875.jpg|thumb|left|Jóhann at AZ]]
After an earlier bid from [[Hamburger SV]] fell through, Jóhann transferred to Dutch club [[AZ Alkmaar|AZ]] on 28 January 2009, signing a 5-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://breidablik.is/frett.php?id_frett%3D4844%26b%3D1 |title=Jóhann Berg til AZ Alkmaar|accessdate=28 January 2009 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722020902/http://breidablik.is/frett.php?id_frett=4844&b=1 |archivedate=22 July 2011 }}</ref>
Having spent two seasons at the club's reserve, Jóhann was given a first team chance under the new management of [[Gertjan Verbeek]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Kolbeinn og Jóhann Berg fá nýjan þjálfara|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/fotbolti/2010/04/22/kolbeinn_og_johann_berg_fa_nyjan_thjalfara/|publisher=mbl.is|language=Icelandic|date=22 April 2010|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> Jóhann returned to the first team from injuries and soon scored his twice, in a 2–2 draw against [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] on 4 November 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leeds United 2 – 2 Charlton impressive goals, most notably of which came against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on Boxing Day, in which he won Goal of the Season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlton Athletic 1 – 1 Cardiff |url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/goal-of-the-season-gudmundsson-wins-competition-2461408.aspx |title=Johann Gudmundsson wins 2014/15 Goal of the Season |publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C. |date=18 May 2015 |accessdate=19 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519205514/http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/goal-of-the-season-gudmundsson-wins-competition-2461408.aspx earning March's goal of the month competition.<ref>{{cite news|title=Blackpool 0 – 3 Charlton Athletic|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31809694|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Jóhann was voted runner-up in the club's player of the season competition after an impressive first campaign, which saw him net a total of 11 goals in 37 matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/charlton-player-of-the-year-2015-jordan-cousins-2438418.aspx |title=Jordan Cousins crowned 2014/15 Player of the Year }}</ref>
Ahead of the 2015–16 season, Jóhann signed a new four-year deal with the club on 22 July 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=NEW DEAL Gudmundsson commits future to Charlton |url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/charlton-johann-gudmundsson-new-four-year-deal-2562930.aspx |accessdate=22 July 2015 |date=22 July 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001158/http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/charlton-johann-gudmundsson-new-four-year-deal-2562930.aspx |archivedate=4 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Jóhann then scored two goals in two matches between 22 August 2015 and 29 August 2015 against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlton Athletic 2 – 1 Hull City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33944301|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 August 2015|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 2 – 1 Charlton Athletic|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34024948|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2015|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> Jóhann was soon on the sidelined for the remainder of December when he was limped off during a match against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/charlton-athletic-preview-burnley-2858362.aspx |title=PREVIEW – Charlton Athletic v Burnley |publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C. |date=18 December 2015 |accessdate=19 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919160916/http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/charlton-athletic-preview-burnley-2858362.aspx |archivedate=19 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> After making his return to the first team, Jóhann went on to score four more goals for the club, as the 2015–16 season progressed, against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Preston North End 2 – 1 Charlton Athletic|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35584417|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 February 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> [[Birmingham F.C.|Birmingham City]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlton Athletic 2 – 1 Birmingham City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35902203|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 April 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlton Athletic 1 – 3 Brighton Hove & Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36060713|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 April 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> and Leeds United.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leeds United 1 – 2 Charlton Athletic|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36118106|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 April 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> Though the club were relegated to [[Football League One|League One]], finishing 22nd place, Jóhann finished the 2015–16 season, making 42 appearances and scoring six times in all competitions. Nevertheless, Jóhann was joint–highest assist-maker in the Championship during the 2015–16 season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Burnley's new assist king Johann Berg Gudmundsson can't wait to start supplying 'great strikers'|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/14676149.Burnley_s_new_assist_king_Johann_Berg_Gudmundsson_can___t_wait_to_start_supplying____great_strikers___/|work=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=11 August 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref>
===Burnley 2016–=== On 19 July 2016, Jóhann joined newly promoted [[Premier League]] team [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on a three-year deal for an undisclosed fee, alongside team–mate, [[Nick Pope (footballer)|Nick Pope]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Johann Berg Gudmundsson & Nick Pope: Burnley sign duo from Charlton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36835053|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> He made his Burnley debut, in the opening match of the season, coming on as a substitute for [[Scott Arfield]] in the 75th minute, in a 1–0 loss against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Burnley 0 – 1 Swansea City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36994442|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 August 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> His first Burnley goal came in a 3-2 win against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 5 November 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Burnley 3–2 Crystal Palace: Late Ashley Barnes strike puts Clarets ninth|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/burnley-vs-c-palace/356437|publisher=Sky Sports|date=5 November 2016|accessdate=7 January 2017}}</ref>
==International career== Jóhann played his first [[Iceland national under-21 football team|U21]] match for [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] on 12 June 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Byrjunarlið U21 gegn Noregi klárt|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/fotbolti/2008/06/12/byrjunarlid_u21_gegn_noregi_klart/|publisher=mbl.is|language=Icelandic|date=12 June 2008|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> Then on 12 August 2008, Jóhann was called up the national team for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jóhann Berg og Hólmar í landsliðinu|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/fotbolti/2008/08/12/johann_berg_og_holmar_i_landslidinu/|publisher=mbl.is|language=Icelandic|date=12 August 2008|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> Jóhann won his first cap for Iceland in a friendly match against [[Azerbaijan national football team|Azerbaijan]], where he set up a goal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ísland gerði jafntefli við Aserbaídsjan|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/fotbolti/2008/08/20/island_gerdi_jafntefli_vid_aserbaidsjan/|publisher=mbl.is|language=Icelandic|date=20 August 2008|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref>
On 6 September 2013 Jóhann scored a hat-trick, the first person to do so for Iceland in 13 years, in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|FIFA World Cup qualifying]] match against [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]], equalizing with the last goal of the match, a left-footed, curling shot from the edge of the 18-yard box in the 91st minute, with the match finishing 4–4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/efstadeild/2013/09/06/johann_bjargadi_stigi_med_thrennu/ |title=Jóhann Berg bjargaði stigi með glæsilegri þrennu |website=Mbl.is |date=6 September 2013 |accessdate=19 July 2016}}</ref>
He was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2016]] squad for Iceland<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ksi.is/landslid/nr/13334 |title=A karla – Lokahópur fyrir EM 2016 |date=9 May 2016 |accessdate=10 May 2016 |language=Icelandic |publisher=Knattspyrnusamband Íslands |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160512081400/http://www.ksi.is/landslid/nr/13334 |archivedate=12 May 2016 |df= }}</ref> and played his first UEFA Euro 2016 match, where he set up a goal for [[Birkir Bjarnason]]. This was the country's first ever goal in a major tournament when Birkir scored the equalizer against Portugal in [[UEFA Euro 2016 Group F#Portugal vs Iceland|their first group match]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/14/portugal-iceland-euro-2016-match-report|title=Match Report: Portugal 1 Iceland 1|date=14 June 2016|work=The Guardian|accessdate=15 June 2016}}</ref> On 27 June 2016, Jóhann played against [[England national football team|England]] in the [[UEFA Euro 2016]] round of 16 at the [[Allianz Riviera|Stade de Nice]], as Iceland upset England with a 2–1 victory to advance to the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news |title=England 1 Iceland 2: Fairytale continues as Hodgson's men crash out |url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/england-1-iceland-2-fairytale-continues-hodgsons-men-crash-out |website=[[FourFourTwo]] |date=27 June 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref>
Jóhann went on to start every match for Iceland until they were eliminated from the tournament against [[France national football team|France]] in the [[UEFA Euro 2016 knockout phase#France vs Iceland|quarter-final]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fletcher|first1=Paul|title=France 5–2 Iceland|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36632457|accessdate=7 January 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 July 2016}}</ref>
In May 2018, he was named in Iceland's 23-man squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/world-cup/0/iceland-world-cup-2018-squad-list-team-guide/|title=Iceland World Cup 2018 squad list and team guide|date=22 June 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref>

Austria U20 | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 18:08, 2 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Ashley Luke Barnes''' (born 30 October 1989) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].
Barnes previously played for [[Paulton Rovers F.C.|Paulton Rovers]], [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], [[Salisbury City F.C.|Salisbury City]], [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]], [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] and [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. He has been [[Cap (sport)|capped]] by Austria at international level, making one appearance for their [[Austria national under-21 football team|under-20]] team.
==Club career== ===Early career and Plymouth Argyle=== As a child, Barnes played on a team called Bath Arsenal, where his teammates included fellow future professional [[Scott Sinclair]].<ref name=hunter/> He began his senior career as a prolific goalscorer with local club [[Paulton Rovers F.C.|Paulton Rovers]] of the [[Southern Football League|Southern League]]. He had an extended trial with Championship club [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] in March 2007, and sufficiently impressed to be awarded with an eighteen-month contract by the club, having scored several goals for the reserve team.<ref>{{cite news |title=Paulton striker impresses Argyle |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/6347653.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 February 2007 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref> He made his Plymouth debut in the first round of the [[2007–08 Football League Cup|League Cup]] in August 2007 against [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], coming on as a substitute for first-team regular [[Sylvan Ebanks-Blake]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Plymouth 2–1 Wycombe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6941834.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref>
He subsequently found first-team opportunities hard to come by, and was sent on loan to [[Football Conference|Conference]] side [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] in November 2007 to gain some experience.<ref>{{cite news |title=Oxford sign deadline day strikers |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oxford_utd/7107832.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 November 2007 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref> Barnes featured five times for Oxford United, including two [[FA Cup]] ties against [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]], before returning to Plymouth. He was sent out on loan again in March 2008 to another Conference club, this time to [[Salisbury City F.C.|Salisbury City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Salisbury bring in Barnes on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/salisbury/7285607.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 March 2008 |accessdate=1 October 2008}}</ref> He featured in five league matches for the club but did not find the back of the net.
Barnes was loaned out for a third time in November 2008 to [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]], with teammate [[Dan Smith (footballer born 1989)|Daniel Smith]].<ref>{{cite news |date=27 November 2008 |url=http://www.pafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1468498,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805150108/http://www.pafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1468498,00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=5 August 2012 |title=On the way |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=27 November 2008}}</ref> He impressed enough for his loan to be extended by a month,<ref>{{cite news |date=5 January 2009 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1509471,00.html |title=Loan extension |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=6 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430225040/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1509471%2C00.html |archivedate=30 April 2009}}</ref> before he was recalled by Plymouth Argyle in January 2009, ahead of the club's match against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].<ref>{{cite news |date=27 January 2009 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1534218,00.html |title=Ashley called back |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=28 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722181904/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1534218%2C00.html |archivedate=22 July 2011}}</ref> He made his league debut for the Pilgrims against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]] at [[Molineux Stadium|Molineux]], scoring his first goal for the club against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]. His performances at the back-end of the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09 season]] were rewarded when he signed a two-year contract extension in May 2009.<ref>{{cite news |date=6 May 2009 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1645008,00.html |title=New deal for Ash |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=14 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509085952/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1645008%2C00.html |archivedate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
He joined [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] on loan until the end of the season in February 2010,<ref>{{cite news |date=9 February 2010 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1960089,00.html |title=Ash To Plainmoor |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=14 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212051251/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1960089%2C00.html |archivedate=12 February 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=10 February 2010 |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12875_5935039,00.html |title=Barnes capture delights Buckle |publisher=skysports.com |accessdate=14 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317023657/http://www.skysports.com/story/0%2C19528%2C12875_5935039%2C00.html |archivedate=17 March 2010 |deadurl=no}}</ref> but returned a month later having made six appearances.<ref>{{cite news |date=12 March 2010 |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1991607,00.html |title=Barnesy back |publisher=pafc.co.uk |accessdate=12 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315125536/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10364~1991607%2C00.html |archivedate=15 March 2010}}</ref>
===Brighton & Hove Albion=== [[File:Ashley Barnes Brighton.jpg|thumb|upright|Barnes playing for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in 2011]]
Barnes subsequently joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |date=25 March 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brighton/8587183.stm |title=Brighton make double loan signing |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328175237/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brighton/8587183.stm |archivedate=28 March 2010 |deadurl=no}}</ref> He scored on his debut against [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] two days later, having been introduced as a substitute ten minutes earlier.<ref>{{cite news |date=27 March 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8568156.stm |title=Brighton 3–0 Tranmere |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401054052/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8568156.stm |archivedate=1 April 2010 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
On 8 July 2010, Barnes signed a two-year contract with Brighton & Hove Albion after transferring for an undisclosed fee from Plymouth Argyle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0,,10433~2086784,00.html |title=Barnes is back |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=8 July 2010 |accessdate=8 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710184325/http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0%2C%2C10433~2086784%2C00.html |archivedate=10 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 12 April 2011, he scored the decisive goal in a 4–3 win at home against [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]], which confirmed their promotion to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Fletcher |first=Paul |title=Brighton 4–3 Dag & Red |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/12968187.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=13 April 2011 |date=11 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110413033537/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/12968187.stm |archivedate=13 April 2011 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Barnes finished the season as Brighton's second-top goalscorer behind [[Glenn Murray]], with 20 goals in 49 appearances.
In the [[2011-12 Football League Championship|2011–12 season]] Barnes remained a first-choice striker for Brighton's return to the Championship. He finished the season as Brighton's leading goalscorer with 14 goals in all competitions, 11 in the league.
On 9 March 2013, Barnes received a red card in stoppage time against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] for attempting to trip up the referee. He was subsequently handed a seven-match suspension by [[the Football Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21804556 |title=Ashley Barnes: FA extends striker's ban to seven games |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 March 2013}}</ref> Fans and manager [[Gus Poyet]] were critical of Barnes for this action as it left the club with only one senior striker available to play, as [[Craig Mackail-Smith]] and [[Will Hoskins]] were already injured for the rest of the season. On his return from the ban on 20 April, Barnes scored two goals in a 6–1 win over [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] and was named man of the match.
===Burnley=== On 10 January 2014, Barnes joined [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] for an undisclosed fee on a three-and-a-half-year deal.<ref>{{cite web |title=Burnley sign Barnes from Brighton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25681552 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 January 2014 |accessdate=10 January 2014}}</ref> On 8 November, he scored the only goal at [[Turf Moor]] to defeat [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and gain Burnley's first win of the [[Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Abraham |first1=Timothy |title=Burnley 1–0 Hull |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29860234 |accessdate=8 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 November 2014}}</ref> He scored a second goal on 13 December, the sole goal in a home victory over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] to take Burnley out of the relegation zone.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanghera |first1=Mandeep |title=Burnley 1–0 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30357668 |accessdate=14 December 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2014}}</ref>
In February 2015, Barnes performed a high tackle on [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea's]] [[Nemanja Matić]], who was sent off for pushing him in retaliation. Barnes did not receive a booking for the challenge, and [[The FA]] confirmed that they would not take retrospective action as that was not normal procedure for attempted tackles.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ashley Barnes escapes FA disciplinary action over horror tackle on Nemanja Matic |url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/ashley-barnes-escapes-fa-disciplinary-action-over-horror-tackle-on-nemanja-matic-31014780.html |accessdate=24 February 2019 |work=Irish Independent |date=23 February 2015}}</ref> Barnes was publicly criticised by Chelsea manager [[José Mourinho]], and said of the criticism "I found that hilarious".<ref name=hunter>{{cite news |last1=Hunter |first1=Andy |title=Ashley Barnes: ‘I got a text saying Mourinho had gone on TV to criticise me. I found it funny’ |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/apr/10/ashley-barnes-burnley-jose-mourinho-matic-chelsea-arsenal |accessdate=24 February 2019 |work=The Guadian |date=10 April 2015}}</ref>
On 24 May 2015, as relegated Burnley finished the season with a win over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], Barnes was taken off with knee cruciate ligament injuries, which would rule him out for the majority of [[2015–16 Football League Championship|the following campaign]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Ashley Barnes: Burnley striker to miss most of next season |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32908544 |accessdate=28 May 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 May 2015}}</ref>
On 3 March 2018, he wrote himself into the history books, scoring his 16th goal in the Premier League to secure a 2–1 victory for Burnley against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. His 16th goal, and his 6th of the season, made him Burnley's leading scorer in the [[Premier League]] since it was formed in 1992.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43178518 |title=Burnley 2–1 Everton |date=3 March 2018 |publisher= |via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.whoscored.com/Players/33386/History/Ashley-Barnes |title=Ashley Barnes – History |website=www.whoscored.com}}</ref>
==International career== Born in Bath to English parents, Barnes would qualify to represent [[Austria]] courtesy of his paternal grandmother, who was from [[Klagenfurt]] if he were to acquire Austrian citizenship.<ref name="Austria">{{cite web |title=Burnley striker Ashley Barnes admits desire to play for Austria |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2017/03/10/mn-burnley-striker-ashley-barnes-admits-desire-to-play-for-austr/ |publisher=HITC |date=20 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=1 August 2008 |url=http://paultonroversafc.co.uk/joomla/content/view/63/1/ |title=Ash Called Up For Austria |publisher=paultonroversafc.co.uk |accessdate=14 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824034227/http://paultonroversafc.co.uk/joomla/content/view/63/1/ |archivedate=24 August 2011}}</ref> He was spotted by Austrian officials while on a pre-season tour with Plymouth Argyle in July 2008, and as a result he was called up to their [[Austria national under-21 football team|Under-20 team]] to face [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|Switzerland]] on 19 August 2008, the match was part of a four nation friendly tournament featuring Austria, Germany, Italy, and Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web |title=ÖFB MEDIAINFO 137/2008: FRANZÖSISCHE REFEREES BEI ITALIEN VS ÖSTERREICH/DIE ÖFB KADERLISTEN FÜR U20, U21 UND A-TEAM PLUS TERMINE FÜR DIE KOMMENDEN LÄNDERSPIELE |url=http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11455 |publisher=OFB |accessdate=22 April 2014 |language=German |date=August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924002546/http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11455|archive-date=24 September 2016|dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Barnes made his debut as a substitute in the 73rd minute replacing [[FC Wacker Innsbruck (2002)|FC Wacker Innsbruck's]] [[Julius Perstaller]] in front of 250 spectators.<ref>{{cite web |title=VIELE CHANCEN, ABER DIE SCHWEIZ TRIFFT |url=http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11550 |publisher=OFB |accessdate=22 April 2014 |language=German |date=August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924002602/http://www.oefb.at/show_berichtdetail.php?ber_id=11550|archive-date=24 September 2016|dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Barnes said in April 2015 that he had had no further contact with the [[Austrian Football Association]], and stated that he was open to representing either England or Austria at senior level if given the opportunity.<ref name=hunter/> In March 2017, whilst playing in the [[Premier League]] for Burnley, he expressed his desire to represent the [[Austria national football team|national senior side]].<ref name="Austria"/> His form in the 2017–18 season led to calls in Austria for him to receive a national team call-up, and manager [[Franco Foda]] confirmed in March 2018 that he was monitoring Barnes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/austria/story/3403243/burnley-striker-ashley-barnes-being-monitored-by-austria-franco-foda |title=Austria coach monitoring Burnley's Barnes |date=2 March 2018 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref>
==Personal life== Barnes is from [[Dunkerton, Somerset]], near Bath.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Delighted-Barnes-sets-sights-flight-Brighton/story-12305135-detail/story.html |title=Delighted Barnes sets sights on top flight with Brighton |date=21 April 2011 |publisher=Western Daily Press |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503203332/http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Delighted-Barnes-sets-sights-flight-Brighton/story-12305135-detail/story.html |archivedate=3 May 2014 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> He attended [[Writhlington School]], near Bath.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.writhlington.org.uk/sixth-form/alumni/ |title=Alumni – Writhlington School |website=www.writhlington.org.uk}}</ref>

Brady''' (born 14 January 1992) is an Irish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] and a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left-back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland national team]]. Brady began his career in the [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United academy]]. However, after featuring just once for United's first team, he joined [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] initially on loan and then permanently in 2013. He made 124 appearances for the ''Tigers'', helping them reach the [[2014 FA Cup Final]]. In July 2015, he joined Norwich City for £7 million where he suffered relegation to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] with the club in 2016. He returned to the Premier League where he became Burnley's record signing in January 2017 when he completed a transfer for a fee reported to be around £13 million. Brady has represented Ireland at all youth levels. After becoming their highest under-21 scorer of all time with seven goals, Brady made his senior international debut against [[Oman national football team|Oman]] in 2012, scoring and setting up two more goals in a 4–1 victory. He has earned over 30 caps for his country and represented them at [[UEFA Euro 2016]], scoring two goals during the tournament. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Born in [[Baldoyle]], Dublin, Brady attended [[Pobalscoil Neasáin]] and was part of their under-16 All-Ireland Championship winning team. He was spotted by [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] scouts while playing for St. Kevin's Boys, and joined the club's academy shortly after his 16th birthday in January 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/soccer/who-robbie-brady-everything-you-8159139|title=Who is Robbie Brady? Everything you need to know about the Ireland star|work=Irish Mirror|first=David|last=Maher|date=10 June 2016|accessdate=25 January 2017}} He made his first appearance for Manchester United in an under-18s match against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 19 January 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/The-Academy/Academy-News/2008/Jan/U18s-Liverpool-0-United-1.aspx|title=U18s: Liverpool 0 United 1|publisher=Manchester United F.C.|first=Ben|last=Hibbs|date=19 January 2008|accessdate=19 December 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929212822/http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/The-Academy/Academy-News/2008/Jan/U18s-Liverpool-0-United-1.aspx|archive-date=29 September 2012|dead-url=yes}} His reserve team debut came just two months later, in a 3–1 win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].{{cite web|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/Reserves/Reserves-News/2008/Mar/Reserves-United-3-Newcastle-1.aspx|title=Reserves: United 3 Newcastle 1|publisher=Manchester United F.C.|first=Steve|last=Bartram|date=27 March 2008|accessdate=19 December 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915045409/http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/Reserves/Reserves-News/2008/Mar/Reserves-United-3-Newcastle-1.aspx|archive-date=15 September 2012|dead-url=yes}} In July 2008, Brady signed on as an academy scholar, and cemented his place in the under-18s throughout the following two seasons, as well as playing for the reserves. In the 2010–11 season, Brady graduated to the reserve team on a permanent basis.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ie/slideshow/3712/1/the-five-best-young-irish-players|title=The five best young
