|nationalcaps1 = 13 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 21:20, 27 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 15 March 2014 }} '''Phillip Anthony Bardsley''' (born 28 June 1985) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]]. Although born in England, Bardsley qualifies for Scotland through his [[Glasgow]]-born father.<ref>[http://sport.stv.tv/football/scottish-premier/rangers/201311-phil-bardsley-called-into-scotland-squad-for-euro-2012-games/ Phil Bardsley called into Scotland squad for Euro 2012 games]</ref>
Bardsley began his career with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] where he made 18 appearances in five seasons at the club. During that time, he was loaned to several clubs, including [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]], [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]], [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].
He joined [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in January 2008 for an initial fee of £850,000. Bardsley established himself as a regular at the [[Stadium of Light]] under [[Steve Bruce]] and [[Martin O'Neill]] and he won the player of the year award in [[2010–11 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2010–11]]. He lost his place in the team in [[2012–13 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2012–13]] after a falling-out with manager [[Paolo Di Canio]], before returning to the first team under [[Gus Poyet]]. Under Poyet, Bardsley helped Sunderland to avoid relegation in [[2013–14 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2013–14]] and reach the [[2014 Football League Cup Final]], in which they lost 3–1 to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].
After his Sunderland contract expired in June 2014, Bardsley joined [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on a free transfer. He spent three seasons with the club before joining [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in July 2017.
==Early life== Bardsley attended [[Hope High School (Salford)|Hope High School]] in his hometown, Salford, along with former United teammates [[Mark Redshaw]] and [[Mark Howard (defender)|Mark Howard]]. Bardsley started his career with Charlestown Lads Club also with Redshaw before signing for Manchester United.<ref name="Sport Vibe">{{cite web|title=Mark Redshaw – FC Oss |url=http://www.sportsvibe.co.uk/features/football/brits-abroad-11265/mark-redshaw-fc-oss-12492/ |work=Sports Vibe |accessdate=23 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407012507/http://www.sportsvibe.co.uk/features/football/brits-abroad-11265/mark-redshaw-fc-oss-12492/ |archivedate=7 April 2012 }}</ref> He grew up near Manchester United's old training ground, [[The Cliff (training ground)|The Cliff]], and would often go there on his school holidays to see the players train. Prior to his departure for Sunderland, he was the only current player who progressed through all the levels of the academy, starting out at the club at the age of 8.<ref name="Sport Vibe"/>
==Club career==
===Manchester United=== After coming through the club's youth system, Bardsley was a regular in Manchester United's under-17 team from the 2000–01 season, before progressing to the under-19s from the 2002–03 season. He continued in the under-19s in [[2003–04 Manchester United F.C. season|2003–04]], but appeared more frequently in the reserves before making his first-team debut in a 2–0 defeat to [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on 3 December 2003 in the fourth round of the [[2003–04 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Baggies bounce Man Utd out|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3246994.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 March 2015|date=3 December 2003}}</ref> He made a second appearance for the first team in the 3–0 [[FA Cup]] fourth round win over [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] on 25 January 2004, before going on a four-month loan to Manchester United's Belgian feeder club, [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp]], on 30 January.<ref>{{cite web|title=Northampton 0–3 Man Utd|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/3403761.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 March 2015|date=25 January 2004}}</ref> He made six appearances for Royal Antwerp, including a 4–0 defeat to [[Club Brugge K.V.|Club Brugge]] on 8 February 2004, in which he was sent off for two bookable offences.<ref>{{cite web |title=Club Brugge K.V. 4–0 R. Antwerp F.C. |url=http://www.rafcmuseum.be/wedstrijdarchief/wedstrijdfiche.php?matchid=1730 |publisher=R.A.F.C.-Museum (Royal Antwerp FC) |accessdate=23 May 2014 }}</ref>
After returning to Manchester United at the end of 2003–04, Bardsley made three appearances on the club's [[2004–05 Manchester United F.C. season|2004–05]] pre-season tour of the United States, playing against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] and [[A.C. Milan|Milan]]. He made another promising start to the [[2005–06 Manchester United F.C. season|2005–06]] season, and an injury to [[Gary Neville]] gave him plenty of opportunities to play between August and November 2005. He was regularly named as a substitute for much of the rest of the season, before going on loan to [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 16 March 2006. He played six matches and scored an own goal in the first minute of a 1–1 draw at home to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Burnley 1–1 Southampton|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/4842462.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 March 2015|date=28 March 2006}}</ref>
====Loan to Rangers==== Bardsley again made a significant contribution to Manchester United's pre-season programme in [[2006–07 Manchester United F.C. season|2006–07]], but on 16 August, he was sent out on loan again, this time to [[Scottish Premier League]] club [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Rangers sign up Bardsley on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/r/rangers/4799891.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2006 |accessdate=14 April 2012 }}</ref> On 9 September 2006, he scored his only goal for Rangers against [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]] with a terrific long-range free kick.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/5325254.stm |title=Rangers 4–0 Falkirk |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 September 2006 |accessdate=24 October 2009 }}</ref> He was sent off against [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Hibernians 2–1 Rangers |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/scot_prem/5345670.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 September 2006 |accessdate=14 April 2012 }}</ref> and therefore missed the [[Old Firm]] match against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]. On 17 October, it was reported that Bardsley was involved in a training ground disagreement with manager [[Paul Le Guen]] and his future at Rangers appeared to be in doubt.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bardsley axed after boss bust-up |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rangers/6061000.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 October 2006 }}</ref> Indeed, Bardsley never played for Rangers again and returned to Manchester United in December.<ref>{{cite news |title=Old Trafford duo make Ibrox exit |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rangers/6216885.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 December 2006 }}</ref>
====Loan to Aston Villa==== On 8 January 2007, Bardsley joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on loan until the end of the season and played his first [[Premier League]] match against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 20 January.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tactical Formation |work=Football-Lineups.com |url=http://www.football-lineups.com/wiki/_match3473.php |accessdate=3 February 2007 }}</ref> It was announced on 1 May that Bardsley would be returning to Manchester United when his loan deal with Villa ran out as manager [[Martin O'Neill]] did not want to make the move permanent.<ref>{{cite news |title=Phil's United Return |url=http://www.avfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/HeadlinesDetail/0,,10265~1019107,00.html |publisher=Aston Villa F.C. |date=1 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006014134/http://www.avfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/HeadlinesDetail/0,,10265~1019107,00.html |archivedate=6 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Loan to Sheffield United==== After playing what would turn out to be his last match for the Manchester United first team against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] in the League Cup on 26 September 2007, it was confirmed on 15 October Bardsley would join [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on loan until January 2008.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd's Bardsley in Blades loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/7044929.stm |publisher=BBC Sport (British Broadcasting Corporation) |date=15 October 2007 |accessdate=24 May 2014 }}</ref> He made his full debut for the Blades a few days later in a 1–1 draw with [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] at Bramall Lane. Despite Sheffield United agreeing a deal with Manchester United to sign him permanently,<ref name="Bardsley loan">{{cite news |title=Bardsley Deal Fear |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/sheffield-united/Bardsley-deal-fear.3645259.jp |work=Sheffield Star |publisher=Johnston Press Digital Publishing |date=7 January 2008 |accessdate=22 January 2008 }}</ref> Bardsley left at the end of his loan deal in January 2008 after playing 16 matches.
===Sunderland=== [[File:Phil Bardsley 2.jpg|thumb|Bardsley for Sunderland in a pre-season friendly against [[York City F.C.|York City]]]] On 22 January 2008, Bardsley joined Sunderland on a three-and-a-half-year contract in a deal worth an initial £850,000, potentially rising to £2 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland complete Bardsley signing |url=http://www.safc.com/news/?page_id=14043 |work=safc.com |publisher=Sunderland AFC |date=22 January 2008 |accessdate=22 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080124045034/http://www.safc.com/news/?page_id=14043 |archivedate=24 January 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bardsley makes Sunderland switch|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/7203422.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=23 January 2008}}</ref> He made his debut in a 2–0 win against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in the Premier League on 29 January.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland 2–0 Birmingham|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7210578.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=29 January 2008}}</ref> Bardsley played 11 times under [[Roy Keane]] in [[2007–08 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2007–08]] as Sunderland successfully avoided relegation by three points.<ref>{{cite web|title=Keane brings out best in Bardsley|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/7340689.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=10 April 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Angry Keane prepares to wield axe|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/7381027.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=5 May 2008}}</ref> On 27 August 2008 Bardsley scored his first goal in English football in a 2–1 victory against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Nottm Forest 1–2 Sunderland (aet) |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7576515.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 August 2008 |accessdate=3 November 2009 |first=Andrew |last=McKenzie}}</ref> Bardsley lost out to [[Pascal Chimbonda]] during the first half of the [[2008–09 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2008–09]] campaign before regaining his place in the team in November 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bardsley determined to keep place|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/7742062.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 May 2014|date=21 November 2008}}</ref> He retained his place under [[Ricky Sbragia]], playing in total 33 times in 2008–09 as Sunderland survived relegation on the final day of the season.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sanghera|first=Mandeep|title=Sunderland 2–3 Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8048317.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 May 2014|date=24 May 2009}}</ref><ref name="2008/09"/>
[[File:Phil Bardsley cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Bardsley playing for Sunderland in 2012]] Bardsley kept his place under new manager [[Steve Bruce]] for the first half of the [[2009–10 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2009–10 season]] until loan signing [[Alan Hutton]] took his place in February 2010. From there until the end of the campaign Bardsley was mainly used as a substitute and due his lack of playing time, Bardsley stated that he may have to consider leaving.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bardsley hints at Sunderland exit |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/football/teams/s/sunderland/8595617.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=30 March 2010 }}</ref> However Hutton didn't make his move permanent and Bardsley was able to reclaim his place in the side and in November 2010, he signed a new three-and-a-half-year deal running until summer 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley signs Sunderland contract extension|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/9155587.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=7 November 2010}}</ref> He scored his first league goal against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on 5 January 2011 with a 25-yard strike in a 1–0 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9331248.stm|title=Aston Villa 0–1 Sunderland|date=5 January 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=5 January 2011}}</ref> He then scored his second of the season with another long range strike against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 1 February 2012 in a 4–2 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland 2–4 Chelsea |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9379797.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=31 May 2014 |date=1 February 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Phil Bardsley praises strong spirit in Sunderland squad |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/9385002.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=31 May 2014 |date=2 February 2011 }}</ref> He scored another long-range goal on 9 April 2011 in a 3–2 defeat against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland 2–3 West Brom|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9447800.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=9 April 2011}}</ref> In total Bardsley played 37 times in [[2010–11 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2010–11]] as the Black Cats finished in 10th position.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley angry at Sunderland run|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13053350|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref> Bardsley's consistent performances during the campaign earned him the Player of the year award.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley wins supporters Player of the Year|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/phil-bardsley-wins-supporters-player-1398744|work=Chronicle Live|accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref>
Bardsley made a poor start to the [[2011–12 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2011–12]] season as he was sent-off in a 1–0 defeat against [[Tyne–Wear derby|rivals]] [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 21 August 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Magowan|first1=Alistair|title=Sunderland 0–1 Newcastle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14514549|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> He was then handed a retrospective four-match ban by [[The Football Association|the FA]] for an altercation [[Juan Mata]] in a 2–1 defeat by Chelsea on 10 September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland's Phil Bardsley to serve four-game FA ban|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14905428|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 June 2014|date=14 September 2011}}</ref> Despite this Bardsley retained his place in the side under [[Martin O'Neill]], playing a total of 37 matches as Sunderland finished in 13th position.<ref name="2011/12"/> He missed the start of the [[2012–13 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2012–13]] campaign after undergoing ankle surgery in August 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hunter|first1=James|title=Phil Bardsley still a top Cat, declares Martin O'Neill|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/phil-bardsley-still-top-cat-1372396|website=Chronicle Live|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> Bardsley returned to the side at the end of October 2012, with the team struggling near the bottom of the table.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley targets Sunderland first-team run|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20431617|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 June 2014|date=21 November 2012}}</ref> [[Paolo Di Canio]] replaced O'Neill in March 2013 and he guided the team to back to back victories over Newcastle United and Everton lifting the club away from the relegation zone.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Magowan|first1=Alistair|title=Newcastle 0–3 Sunderland|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22056537|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 June 2014|date=14 April 2013}}</ref> Bardsley scored in the penultimate match of the season in a 1–1 draw with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 12 May 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland 1–1 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22417765|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> Bardsley missed the final match of the season away at [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] after he and [[Matthew Kilgallon]] were pictured visiting a casino, angering Di Canio who vowed never to play the pair again.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2326902/Phil-Bardsley-pictured-lying-50-notes-casino-floor.html |location=London |work=Daily Mail |title=Bardsley pictured on casino floor in pile of £50 notes... leaving strict Sunderland boss Di Canio furious }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=You'll NEVER play for me again! Di Canio lays into Bardsley after shamed Sunderland star poses with £50 notes in casino... and you can read the Italian's amazing 24-minute rant right here |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2327252/Paolo-Di-Canio-says-Phil-Bardsley-play-Sunderland-again.html |work=Daily Mail |location=London }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Paolo Di Canio says misbehaving Sunderland players will leave|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22590459|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> Di Canio also fined Bardsley as well as six other Sunderland players for "indiscipline" which prompted an investigation by [[Professional Footballers' Association|the PFA]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|title=Paolo Di Canio: PFA investigates decision to fine Sunderland players|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22608572|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 June 2014|date=21 May 2013}}</ref>
Bardsley began the [[2013–14 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2013–14]] season playing with the under-21s and whilst playing against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 12 August 2013 he broke his foot ending Di Canio's attempts to sell him.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland defender Phil Bardsley faces 10 weeks out through injury|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11695/8868332/sunderland-defender-phil-bardsley-faces-10-weeks-out-through-injury|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref> On 20 August 2013, Bardsley was suspended by Sunderland after mocking the club's opening day defeat to Fulham on a social media site.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland suspended Bardsley for mocking Twitter post|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/231487.html|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland: Phil Bardsley suspended amid investigation|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23768404|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 June 2014|date=20 August 2013}}</ref> His suspension was lifted on 4 September 2013 after he apologised.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley: Sunderland lift suspension after he apologises|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23962761|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 June 2014|date=4 September 2013}}</ref> Di Canio was sacked and replaced by [[Gus Poyet]] in October 2013 and brought Bardsley back into the first-team.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley set to make his Sunderland return at Swansea|url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/sport/phil-bardsley-set-make-sunderland-6177479|website=The Journal|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref> He made a poor start on his return, scoring an own goal in a 4–0 defeat away at [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Swansea 4–0 Sunderland|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24503990|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 June 2014|date=19 October 2013}}</ref> His form improved thereafter scoring against Southampton in the League Cup and the only goal in a 1–0 win over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on 10 November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland 1–0 Man City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24792966|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 June 2014|date=10 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sunderland's Phil Bardsley trying to regain fans' trust|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24897725|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 June 2014|date=11 November 2013}}</ref> He scored against his former club Manchester United in the 2nd leg of the League Cup semi-final as Sunderland progressed to the final on penalties.<ref>{{cite web|title=Man Utd 2–1 Sunderland|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25740123|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 June 2014|date=22 January 2014}}</ref> Bardsley played the full match of the [[2014 Football League Cup Final]] as Sunderland lost 3–1 to Manchester City.<ref>{{cite web|title=Man City 3–1 Sunderland|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26311649|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref> Bardsley played a total of 33 times in 2013–14 as Sunderland finished in 14th position.<ref name="2013/14"/>
===Stoke City=== With Bardsley's Sunderland contract due to expire at the end of June 2014, other clubs were free to approach him from January 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bardsley's future is still unclear|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/sport/football/11167438.Bardsley_s_future_is_still_unclear/|website=Daily Echo|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref> On 22 May 2014, Bardsley signed a three-year contract with [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Potters Complete Bardsley Signing |url=http://www.stokecityfc.com/news/article/potters-complete-bardsley-signing-1570484.aspx |publisher=stokecityfc.com (Stoke City FC) |date=22 May 2014 |accessdate=22 May 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke sign Phil Bardsley from Sunderland on three-year deal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27529040|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref> He made his Premier League debut for Stoke on the opening day of the [[2014–15 Stoke City F.C. season|2014–15]] season in a 1–0 defeat against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 0–1 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28718337|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref> Bardsley established himself as a regular under [[Mark Hughes]] but struggled with discipline, picking up nine yellow cards by March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley cool on yellow peril ahead of Albion trip|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Phil-Bardsley-cool-yellow-peril-ahead/story-26141659-detail/story.html|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=11 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150313132751/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Phil-Bardsley-cool-yellow-peril-ahead/story-26141659-detail/story.html|archivedate=13 March 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Bardsley played 30 times for Stoke in the 2014–15 season as Stoke finished in 9th position.<ref name="2014/15"/>
Bardsley lost his place in the Stoke squad for the [[2015–16 Stoke City F.C. season|2015–16]] season following the arrival of [[Glen Johnson (English footballer)|Glen Johnson]] from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite web|title=I've got no plans to leave says Phil Bardsley|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-ve-got-plans-leave-says-Phil-Bardsley/story-28236778-detail/story.html|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=2 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151128084225/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-ve-got-plans-leave-says-Phil-Bardsley/story-28236778-detail/story.html|archivedate=28 November 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Despite missing out on league appearances Bardsley played a part in Stoke's [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] campaign. He was sent-off in the fourth round against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and scored a 30-yard free kick in the quarter final victory over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–1 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34577998|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2–0 Sheff Wed|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34907303|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref> Following injury to Johnson in February, Bardsley took his place back in the side until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley insists rival Glen Johnson is still his big mate|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Phil-Bardsley-insists-rival-Glen/story-28986545-detail/story.html|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=23 May 2016}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He made 17 appearances for Stoke in 2015–16 as Stoke again finished in 9th position.<ref name="2015/16"/>
Bardsley scored a rare goal in a 4–0 [[EFL Cup]] victory over [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]] on 23 August 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stevenage 0–4 Stoke|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37091171|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> He suffered a knee injury on November which ruled him out for three months.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke City: Phil Bardsley expected to be out until the New Year|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/stoke-city-phil-bardsley-expected-to-be-out-until-the-new-year/story-29927298-detail/story.html|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=23 May 2017}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He returned to the side in February but after getting sent-off against Chelsea on 18 March 2017 he was unable to get back into the team.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–2 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39240187|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> Speaking in April 2017 Bardsley revealed that he is in limbo over whether he will be offered a new contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley in limbo over Stoke City contract|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/phil-bardsley-in-limbo-over-stoke-city-contract/story-30264035-detail/story.html|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=23 May 2017}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Bardsley played 16 times in [[2016–17 Stoke City F.C. season|2016–17]] as Stoke finished in 13th position.<ref name="2016/17"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2016/17 Premier League season review|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11701/10887143/stoke-201617-premier-league-season-review|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> He signed a contract extension with Stoke on 26 May 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley signs up for another year at Stoke City|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/phil-bardsley-signs-up-for-another-year-at-stoke-city/story-30355653-detail/story.html|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=26 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170526124139/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/phil-bardsley-signs-up-for-another-year-at-stoke-city/story-30355653-detail/story.html|archivedate=26 May 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Burnley=== On 25 July 2017, Bardsley completed a transfer to Premier League club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], signing a two-year contract.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2017/july/clarets-make-bardsley-fourth-summer-signing/|title=Clarets Make Bardsley Fourth Summer Signing|publisher=Burnley Official Site|date=25 July 2017}}</ref>
==International career== On 6 October 2010, Bardsley received a call-up for the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] national team for the [[Euro 2012 Qualifiers|Euro 2012 qualifier]] against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] on 8 October 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/9059609.stm |title=Sunderland's Phil Bardsley called in to Scots squad |publisher=BBC News |first=Clive |last=Lindsay |date=8 October 2010}}</ref> He qualifies because his father was born in Glasgow.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article601171.ece|title=Phil Good Factor |location=London |work=The Times |first=Simon |last=Buckland |date=15 October 2006}}</ref> He made his debut on 11 October 2010 in a 3–2 defeat by World and European champions [[Spain national football team|Spain]], filling in for the injured [[Alan Hutton]].
==Style of play== Bardsley plays at [[right back]] and describes himself as a modern full-back.— "Since I started playing professionally, the game has changed and you have to be really, really fit because a full-back is expected to get up and down the pitch. I like to defend and be aggressive, but also get forward to create chances and create goals, it's all part of being a modern-day full-back."<ref>{{cite web|title=Phil Bardsley ready to win over new fans|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Phil-Bardsley-ready-win-new-fans/story-22082420-detail/story.html|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=11 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402111820/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Phil-Bardsley-ready-win-new-fans/story-22082420-detail/story.html|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Coaching career== In May 2017, Bardsley took a [[UEFA B Licence]] course with the [[Irish Football Association]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Video: Stoke defender Phil Bardsley looks after his long-term future at the UEFA B License course|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/video-news/video-stoke-defender-phil-bardsley-looks-after-his-longterm-future-at-the-uefa-b-license-course-35754773.html|website=The Belfast Telegraph|accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Bardsley married glamour model [[Tanya Robinson]] in 2014, with whom he has three children.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wife of Scotland football star Phil Bardsley reveals how she was sexually assaulted in hotel by worker|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/wife-scotland-football-star-phil-4975273|website=Daily Record|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref> Bardsley's grandfather, John Lancaster, died in a car crash in October 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former Manchester United footballer Phil Bardsley 'inconsolable' after grandfather dies in a car crash|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/footballer-phil-bardsley-inconsolable-after-12077468|last=Bourne|first=Dianne|date=25 October 2016|website=Manchester Evening News|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref>

Vydra''' ({{IPA-cs|ˈmacɛj ˈvɪdra}}, born 1 May 1992) is a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|striker]] for English club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic national team]]. He has previously played for FC Chotěboř, [[FC Vysočina Jihlava|Vysočina Jihlava]], [[FC Baník Ostrava|Baník Ostrava]], [[Club Brugge K.V.|Club Brugge]], [[Udinese Calcio|Udinese]] and [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]. He has also spent two loan spells at Watford. ==Club career== Vydra joined [[FC Baník Ostrava|Baník Ostrava]] from [[FC Vysočina Jihlava|Vysočina Jihlava]] in January 2010 at the age of 17 for 20 million [[Czech koruna|CZK]] (€765,000).{{cite web |first=Jaromír|last=Novák |url=http://fotbal.idnes.cz/mlady-utocnik-vydra-jde-z-jihlavy-do-ostravy-za-temer-dvacet-milionu-1i1-/fotbal.asp?c=A100108_161937_fotbal_mn |title=Mladý útočník Vydra jde z Jihlavy do Ostravy za téměř dvacet milionů |language=Czech |publisher=iDNES.cz |date=8 January 2010|accessdate=9 May 2010}} He spent six months at Baník Ostrava, where he scored four goals in 14 matches. ===Udinese=== In June 2010, Vydra moved to [[Serie A]] side [[Udinese Calcio|Udinese]] and was also voted by sports journalists the [[Golden Ball (Czech Republic)|Czech Revelation of the Year]] for his performances at [[FC Baník Ostrava|Baník Ostrava]] in the [[Gambrinus liga 2009–10|2009–10 season]].{{cite web |first=Jaromír|last=Novák |url=http://fotbal.idnes.cz/na-jare-hral-o-titul-ted-utocnik-vydra-sleduje-jak-je-jeho-novy-tym-posledni-16f-/fot_zahranici.asp?c=A100929_140946_fot_zahranici_mn |title=Na jaře hrál o titul, teď útočník Vydra sleduje, jak je jeho nový tým poslední |language=Czech |publisher=iDNES.cz |date=29 September 2010|accessdate=29 September 2010}} He joined [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]] on loan in August 2011 but returned to Udinese having played just two games due to an injury. ====Watford (loan)==== In July 2012, it was confirmed he had been loaned to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] for the [[2012–13 Watford F.C. season|2012–13 season]].[http://www.watfordfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10400~2865682,00.html "Official: Hornets delighted with a magnificent seven signings"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120802115016/http://www.watfordfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10400~2865682%2C00.html |date=2 August 2012 }}. Watford Football Club. 30 July 2012. Retrieved 30 July 2012. Vydra scored his first goal for Watford when he netted the winner against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 18 August 2012, in a game which finished 3–2.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19221446 |title=Crystal Palace 2–3 Watford |publisher=BBC |date=18 August 2012 |accessdate=21 August 2012}} He scored a goal against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on 10 November.{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20121110/watford-live_2247585_2975550 |title=LEEDS 0, WATFORD 1 (Vydra 27) |publisher=Leeds United Official Website |date=10 November 2012 |accessdate=10 November 2012}} Vydra then scored goals in successive matches in a 2–0 win against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 22 December 2012 and in a 3–1 away win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on 29 December 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/121229-brighton-v-watford-566781.aspx|title=BRIGHTON 1, WATFORD 3 (Vydra x2)|publisher=Watford Official Website|date=29 December 2012|accessdate=29 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130105032916/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/121229-brighton-v-watford-566781.aspx|archivedate=5 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} He scored another brace on 12 January 2013 against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]. Vydra carried on his rich vein of form by netting another goal the week after, on 19 January 2013 against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield]] and then netted his third goal in as many games a week later, scoring twice on 26 January 2013 in a 3–0 win away to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]. He was in fine form, and netted another goal in his next start against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton]] on 2 February 2013. The match eventually finished 2–1 to Watford, with Vydra assisting [[Almen Abdi]]'s winning goal. After three matches without a goal, Vydra netted his 20th goal of the campaign in a 2–1 win over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 23 February 2013. On 25 March 2013 it was announced that he had won the 2012–13 [[Football League Championship|Championship]] Player of the Season award in his first season in English football.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21922979|title=Football League Awards: Matej Vydra named Player of the Year|work=BBC Sport|date=25 March 2013|accessdate=12 May 2013}} Vydra won the award ahead of [[Glenn Murray]] of [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]]'s [[Tom Ince|Thomas Ince]]. Despite going on a run in which he didn't score in 13 games,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22515182|title=Watford boss Gianfranco Zola 'lost it' after play-off winner|work=BBC Sport|date=13 May 2013|accessdate=14 May 2013}} he went on to score twice in the semi-final of the end-of-season play-offs in a 3–2 aggregate win over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22417772|title=Watford 3–1 Leicester (agg 3–2)|work=BBC Sport|date=12 May 2013|accessdate=12 May 2013}} Vydra's season at Watford finished in disappointment as his club lost the chance to be promoted to the [[Premier League|English top-flight]] after losing the play-off final against Crystal Palace and he injured his ankle during the match, having to be substituted at half time.{{cite news|url=http://fotbal.idnes.cz/fotbalista-matej-vydra-zraneni-a-mozny-prestup-fr8-/fot_zahranici.aspx?c=A130528_131535_fot_zahranici_pes|title=Vydra přišel o postup a možná i o Itálii. Ale brzy začne řešit přestup|language=Czech|work=idnes.cz|date=28 May 2013|accessdate=1 June 2013}} ====West Bromwich Albion (loan)==== Vydra joined [[Premier League]] club [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on a season-long loan deal on 13 August 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23680716|title=West Brom sign Udinese's Matej Vydra on season-long loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 August 2013|accessdate=13 August 2013}} He scored his first goal for the club on 21 December 2013, equalising for West Brom in a 1–1 Premier League draw against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/dec/21/west-bromwich-albion-hull-city-premier-league|title=Hull City denied victory at Hawthorns as Matej Vydra rescues West Brom|publisher=The Guardian|date=21 December 2013|accessdate=22 May 2014}} On 22 February 2014, Vydra scored his second goal for West Brom, equalising in a 1–1 draw against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/west-brom-1-fulham-1-match-report-matej-vydra-scores-late-equaliser-for-the-baggies-after-clanger-from-fulhams-goalkeeper-9146402.html|title=West Brom 1 Fulham 1 match report: Goalkeeper’s error denies Felix Magath opening victory|publisher=The Independent|date=22 February 2014|accessdate=22 May 2014}} His third goal for the club came in a 3–3 draw against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham]], with Vydra scoring the game's first goal after 28 seconds.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/10762216/West-Bromwich-Albion-3-Tottenham-Hotspur-3-match-report.html|title=West Bromwich Albion 3 Tottenham Hotspur 3: match report|publisher=The Telegraph|date=12 April 2014|accessdate=22 May 2014}} ====Return to Watford==== On 26 June 2014, Watford announced they had re-signed Vydra on a season-long loan from |date=2014-06-26 |accessdate=2016-01-21}} Vydra made a scoring return as he netted in Watford's 3–0 opening day win over Bolton Wanderers on 9 August 2014.{{cite score as Watford beat Brighton & Hove Albion 2–0 at the [[Falmer Stadium]] thus securing Watford's promotion back to the Premier League, thanks to other results going their way,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32362059 |title=BBC Sport – Brighton & Hove Albion 0–2 Watford |website=Bbc.co.uk |date=2015-04-25 |accessdate=2016-01-21}} with Vydra scoring 16 goals in the [[EFL Championship]] to help earn promotion.{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=56676&season_id=144 |title= Games played by Matej Vydra in 2014/2015 web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com//news/article/150629-watford-fc-vydra-signs-2511955.aspx |title=OFFICIAL: Matej Vydra Signs Five-Year Contract With Hornets |website=Watfordfc.com |date=2015-07-01 |accessdate=2016-01-21}} He started the [[2015–16 Watford F.C. season|2015–16]] season behind [[Odion Ighalo]] and [[Troy Deeney]] in the pecking order, on 25 August 2015, he played for Watford in a 1-0 loss against Preston in the [[EFL Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=56676&season_id=145 |title= Games played by Matej Vydra in 2015/2016 web|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/13639327.Vydra_loan_switch_to_Reading_announced/ |title=Vydra loan switch to Reading announced (From Watford Observer) |website=Watfordobserver.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-01-21}} He made his Reading debut on 11 September 2015 in a 5-1 win against [[Ipswich Town]].{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=56676&season_id=145 |title= Games played by Matej Vydra in 2015/2016 |website=Soccerbase |date=26 July 2018 |accessdate=26 July 2018}} He scored his first goal for the club on 31 October in a 1-1 draw against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]].{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=56676&season_id=145 |title= Games played by Matej Vydra in 2015/2016 |website=Soccerbase |date=26 July 2018 |accessdate=26 July 2018}} On 19 January 2016 in a [[FA Cup]] [[2015–16 FA Cup#Third Round Proper|Third Round Replay]], he scored a [[hat-trick]] in a 5–2 comeback victory over [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]].{{cite web|title=Matej Vydra scored a hat-trick as Reading fought from two goals down|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/35288904|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=21 January 2016|date=19 January 2016}} In total he scored 9 goals in 36 appearances in all competitions for the club, finishing the clubs 2nd top scorer (behind [[Nick Blackman]]) for the [[2015–16 Reading F.C. season|2015–16]] season.{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=56676&season_id=145 |title= Games played by Matej Vydra in 2015/2016 |website=Soccerbase |date=26 July 2018 |accessdate=26 July 2018}} ===Derby County=== On 27 August 2016, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] announced that they had signed Watford striker Vydra on a four-year deal, for a fee reported at £8,000,000.{{cite news|title=Matej Vydra left Watford in club record deal|first=Kevin|last=Affleck|date=28 August 2016|url=http://www.wdsport.co.uk/2016/08/matej-vydra-left-watford-in-club-record-deal/|accessdate=20 May 2018|website=WD Sport|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180712184710/http://www.wdsport.co.uk/2016/08/matej-vydra-left-watford-in-club-record-deal/|archive-date=12 July 2018|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} He scored his first goal for the club in a 2–1 loss to [[Blackburn Rovers]] on 24 September 2016.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37392559|title=Derby 1–2 Blackburn |publisher=BBC |date=24 September 2016 |accessdate=27 September 2016}} In his first [[2016–17 Derby County F.C. season|Derby season]] he scored 5 goals, making 33 appearances in the [[EFL Championship]] with 13 of those coming as a substitute,{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=56676|title=Matej Vydra - Football Stats - Derby County - Age 26 - Soccer Base|website=www.soccerbase.com}} with Vydra playing in different positions with the likes of [[Tom Ince]], [[Darren Bent]], [[Johnny Russell (footballer)|Johnny Russell]] and [[David Nugent]] all competing for attacking position roles.{{cite web |url=https://www.dcfc.co.uk/teams/player/matej-vydra |title=MATEJ VYDRA |publisher=Derby County |date=12 July 2018 |accessdate=12 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180712184017/https://www.dcfc.co.uk/teams/player/matej-vydra |archive-date=12 July 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Vydra scored his first hat-trick for the club in a 3–0 away win over [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 25 November 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42034679|title=Middlesbrough 0–3 Derby County |publisher=BBC |date=25 November 2017 |accessdate=25 November 2017}} After the sale of previous season top scorer [[Tom Ince]]{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40456223|title=Huddersfield sign Tom Ince & Danny Williams, Kasey Palmer joins on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 July 2017|accessdate=11 July 2017}} and the acquisitions of Strikers [[Sam Winnall]]{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41118969|title=Sam Winnall: Sheffield Wednesday striker joins Derby in swap with Jacob Butterfield|date=31 August 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} and [[Cameron Jerome]],{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42704331 |title=Cameron Jerome: Derby County sign striker from Norwich City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 January 2018 |accessdate=17 January 2018}}
{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11696/11210559/derby-sign-cameron-jerome-for-1-5m-from-norwich |title=Derby sign Cameron Jerome for £1.5m from Norwich |publisher=Sky Sports |date=16 January 2018 |accessdate=16 January 2018}} Vydra found himself playing in his favoured [[Forward (association football)|second striker]] position behind a central striker of either Winnall, Jerome, [[David Nugent]] or [[Chris Martin (footballer, born 1988)|Chris Martin]]{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11688/11361634/derby-striker-matej-vydra-wins-sky-bet-championship-golden-boot-award|title=Derby striker Matej Vydra wins Sky Bet Championship Golden Boot award|website=skysports.com}} His goals during the 2017–18 season helped Derby reach the playoff semi finals, where they were knocked out over two legs by [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite web|last1=Dean|first1=Sam|title=Ryan Sessegnon blows Derby County away to fire Fulham into play-off final|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/05/14/ryan-sessegnon-fires-fulham-play-off-final-derby-county-blown/|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=14 May 2018}} In April 2018, he was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)|PFA Championship Team of the Year]]{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43808543|title=PFA Championship Team of the Year: Wolves & Fulham trios named in line-u|website=BBC Sport}} and also in the [[2017–18 EFL Championship|EFL Championship]] Team Of The Year.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43641225|title=EFL awards: Tom Cairney, Ruben Neves & Ryan Sessegnon on Championship shortlist|website=BBC Sport}} He scored 22 goals in all competitions and received the Sky Bet Championship Golden Boot after scoring 21 goals in the Championship during the 2017–18 season. On 1 May, Vydra won 3 awards at the clubs end of season awards ceremony winning the Player Of The Year, Players Player Of The Year and the Jack Stamps Player Of The year awards.{{cite web |url=https://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/matej-vydra-named-derby-county-1522787|title=Matej Vydra named Derby County player of the year as he bags a hat-trick of awards|website=Derby Telegraph}} In July 2018, Vydra held talks with fellow [[EFL Championship]] side [[Leeds United]] over a potential move.{{cite web |url=https://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/football/leeds-united/leeds-united-cool-vydra-interest-after-balking-at-fresh-wage-demands-1-9242186|title=Leeds United cool Vydra interest after balking at fresh wage demands|website=Yorkshire Evening Post}} However, after weeks of negotiations, the move broke down over personal terms.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11715/11454244/matej-vydra-move-to-leeds-from-derby-collapses-over-personal-terms|title=Matej Vydra move to Leeds from Derby collapses over personal terms|website=Sky Sports}} ===Burnley=== Burnley have signed Vydra for an undisclosed fee on a three year deal from Derby on 7 August 2018.{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11708/11464931/burnley-sign-matej-vydra-from-derby-county-on-three-year-deal|title=Burnley sign Matej Vydra from Derby County on three-year deal|publisher=Sky Sports|date=7 August 2018|accessdate=7 August 2018}} ==International career== Vydra played for five [[Czech Republic|Czech]] youth national teams between under-16 and under-21 levels. In August 2012 he was called up to the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech]] senior team for the first time, for a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|World Cup qualifying]] match away to [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] and a friendly match against [[Finland national football team|Finland]].{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/watfordfc/watfordfcnews/9896314.Vydra_receives_first_Czech_call_up/ |title=Vydra receives first Czech call up |publisher=Watford Observer |date=28 August 2012 |accessdate=28 August 2012}} Vydra played the first 73 minutes against Denmark, in a game that finished as a goalless draw.[https://www.theguardian.com/football/match/2012/sep/08/denmark-v-czechrepublic "Match stats: Denmark v Czech Republic"]. ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 9 September 2012. He scored his first goal, a header, for the national team on 26 March 2013 in a World Cup qualifier against [[Armenia national football team|Armenia]], to open the scoring in a 3–0 victory. [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] (loan) | caps11= 1 | goals11= 0 | years12= 2014–2015 | clubs12= [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] | caps12= 11 | goals12= 0 | years13= 2015–2017 | clubs13= Richard Legzdins''' (born 28 November 1986) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].
Legzdins began his career with [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], from where he spent time on loan at several lower-division clubs but never played first-team football for his parent club. In 2008, he joined [[Crewe Alexandra]], with whom he made his debut in [[the Football League]], but played only infrequently. He spent the 2010–11 season as [[Football League Two]] club [[Burton Albion]]'s first-choice goalkeeper, earning himself a move to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] of the [[Football League Championship]]. He played 35 matches over three seasons with Derby, mainly in 2012–13, and after a year with [[Leyton Orient]], he rejoined Birmingham City in 2015. After two seasons and 21 appearances, he signed for Burnley.
He qualifies to play international football for [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] via his paternal grandparents.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/local/Saturday-Spotlight--Adam39s-here.1261084.jp |title=Saturday Spotlight – Adam's here to learn |newspaper=Halifax Courier |date=19 November 2005 |accessdate=5 January 2008}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== Legzdins was born in [[Penkridge]], Staffordshire.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Hugman |editor1-first=Barry J. |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2007–08 |publisher=Mainstream |location=Edinburgh |year=2007 |page=245 |isbn=978-1-84596-246-3}}</ref> He came through [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]'s [[Birmingham City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Academy]] system and played his first competitive football in October 2005 on [[loan (association football)|loan]] at [[Alfreton Town F.C.|Alfreton Town]] in the [[Conference North]], four games which included a [[man of the match]] performance away at [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alfretontownfc.com/herefordunited221005report.htm |title=2005/06 season match No.14 |author=Foster, Gordon |publisher=Alfreton Town F.C. |date=23 October 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060115233421/http://www.alfretontownfc.com/herefordunited221005report.htm |archivedate=15 January 2006}}</ref> He then joined [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]] of the [[Conference National]] on a work experience basis,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/halifax_town/4417624.stm |title=Shaymen seal swoop for Legzdins |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 November 2005 |accessdate=5 January 2008}}</ref> where he played 11 games before Birmingham recalled him, concerned that regular [[first-team]] football for Halifax combined with playing for Birmingham's [[reserve team]] was too much for the 19-year-old.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/halifax_town/4642604.stm |title=Shaymen lose City keeper Legzdins |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 January 2006 |accessdate=5 January 2008}}</ref>
[[File:AdamLegzdins cropped.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Warming up before a [[Football League Championship|Championship]] match at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], August 2006]]Legzdins signed his first one-year professional contract in the summer of 2006. Early in the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] he was given a Birmingham squad number because of an injury to first choice keeper [[Maik Taylor]], and was an unused [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] in their [[Football League Championship|Championship]] match at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/ProfilesDetail/0,,10412~35971,00.html |title=Adam Legzdins |publisher=Birmingham City F.C |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514131236/http://www.blues.premiumtv.co.uk/page/ProfilesDetail/0%2C%2C10412~35971%2C00.html |archivedate=14 May 2008 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> In October 2006 he joined [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on loan where he acted as backup to [[Les Pogliacomi]], making one substitute appearance in the [[Football League Trophy]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oldham_athletic/6181952.stm |title=Oldham extend Legzdins' loan deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 November 2006 |accessdate=5 January 2008}}</ref> He then joined [[Macclesfield Town F.C.|Macclesfield Town]] on loan and was expected to go straight into the starting eleven due to injury and suspension,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/macclesfield_town/s/233062_preview_barnet_v_macclesfield |title=Preview: Barnet v Macclesfield |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |author=Carter, Simon |date=12 January 2007 |accessdate=5 January 2008}}</ref> but manager [[Paul Ince]] chose goalkeeping coach [[David Rouse]] instead,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10393~33003,00.html |title=Barnet 1 Macclesfield 0 |last=Brooks |first=Nick |publisher=Macclesfield Town F.C. |date=13 January 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326170152/http://www.mtfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10393~33003%2C00.html |archivedate=26 March 2012 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and Legzdins completed his month's loan without appearing for the club. He played an active part in helping [[Birmingham City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Birmingham reserves]] to the championship of the [[Central League]] Division One Central in 2006–07.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/reserves-clinch-title-with-last-gasp-sone-40164 |title=Reserves clinch title with last-gasp Sone strike |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=26 April 2007 |accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref>
Legzdins was given a further year's contract in summer 2007,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/wright-rejects-new-blues-deal-42583 |title=Wright rejects new Blues deal |author=Tattum, Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=5 July 2007 |accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> and rejoined Halifax on a three months' loan in October 2007,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/halifax_town/7023535.stm |title=Halifax bag Birmingham goalkeeper |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 October 2007 |accessdate=5 January 2008}}</ref> where he played regularly in preference to the more experienced [[Craig Mawson]]. He extended his loan at Halifax until the end of the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08]] season in January 2008,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/halifax_town/7172210.stm |title=Pair end spell with Halifax Town |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2008 |accessdate=4 June 2010}}</ref> and on 9 June 2008 he signed for [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] as a replacement for their departing goalkeepers [[Ben Williams (footballer, born 1982)|Ben Williams]] and [[Owain Fôn Williams]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crewe_alexandra/7443799.stm |title=Crewe confirm signing of Legzdins |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 June 2008 |accessdate=9 June 2008}}</ref> He joined [[Weymouth F.C.|Weymouth]] on a month's loan on 26 March 2009.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ky |last=Capel |url=http://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/sport/4237350.Terras_in_double_swoop/ |title=Terras in double swoop |newspaper=Dorset Echo |date=26 March 2009 |accessdate=26 March 2009}}</ref>
Legzdins made his first team debut for Crewe in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] defeat to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 11 August 2009, after loan goalkeeper [[David Button]] returned to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crewe_alexandra/8197840.stm |title=Legzdins eager for games at Crewe |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 August 2009 |accessdate=23 August 2009}}</ref> and followed this up with his debut in [[the Football League]] on 22 August, keeping a [[clean sheet]] in the 1–0 home win against Hereford United.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.crewealex.net/page/MatchReport/0,,10414~47343,00.html |title=Crewe vs Hereford |publisher=Crewe Alexandra F.C |date=22 August 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826171221/http://www.crewealex.net/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10414~47343%2C00.html |archivedate=26 August 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
===Burton Albion=== He rejected a new one-year contract with Crewe in May 2010 and subsequently signed for League Two team [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] on a two-year contract on 1 July.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crewe_alexandra/8703615.stm |title=Adam Legzdins turns down offer from Crewe Alexandra |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 May 2010 |accessdate=4 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burton_albion/8779568.stm |title=Burton Albion swoop for goalkeeper Adam Legzdins |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 July 2010 |accessdate=1 July 2010}}</ref> He kept a clean sheet on his full debut on 7 August 2010 in a 0–0 draw against [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.burtonalbionfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10950~52650,00.html |title=Burton vs Oxford United |publisher=Burton Albion F.C. |date=7 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319005512/http://www.burtonalbionfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10950~52650%2C00.html |archivedate=19 March 2012 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> After playing in every League game of the 2010–11 season, he was voted Burton Albion Supporters' Player of the Year and Players' Player of the Year.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13294146.stm |title=Adam Legzdins wins Burton Albion awards double |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2011 |accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref>
===Derby County=== After lengthy speculation,<ref name=legzbid>{{cite news |url=http://www.burtonmail.co.uk/Sport/Burton-Albion-FC/Rams-chase-hots-up-for-keeper-Legzdins-30052011.htm |title=Rams chase hots up for keeper Legzdins |first=Tom |last=Sloan |newspaper=Burton Mail |date=30 May 2011 |accessdate=29 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622084032/https://www.burtonmail.co.uk/Sport/Burton-Albion-FC/Rams-chase-hots-up-for-keeper-Legzdins-30052011.htm |archivedate=22 June 2011}}</ref> on 29 June 2011, it was confirmed that Burton and Championship outfit [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] had agreed a transfer fee that would allow Legzdins to join the [[Pride Park Stadium|Pride Park]] club.<ref name="DCFC Move">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13960105.stm|title=Derby County sign Adam Legzdins from Burton Albion|publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 July 2011|accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref> The transfer was completed on 1 July; Legzdins signed a three-year contract. Derby manager [[Nigel Clough]] said that he would be backup to first choice keeper [[Frank Fielding]].<ref name="DCFC Move"/> Legzdins made his debut for Derby away at [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] after Fielding was sent off after only a minute, and contributed to a 2–1 win against their [[Derby County F.C.–Nottingham Forest F.C. rivalry|local rivals]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/14864055.stm |title=Nottm Forest 1–2 Derby |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 September 2011 |accessdate=17 September 2011}}</ref> On 20 March 2012, Legzdins rejoined former club Burton Albion on a month's emergency loan.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17443314 |title=Burton bring back Derby County goalkeeper Adam Legzdins |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 March 2012 |accessdate=20 March 2012}}</ref> He was restricted to just one appearance by a hip injury suffered in a 1–0 defeat against [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] and returned to Derby on 17 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/17042012/63/legzdins-rams.html |title=Legzdins back with Rams |publisher=Eurosport Yahoo |date=17 April 2012 |accessdate=17 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120726233537/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/17042012/63/legzdins-rams.html |archivedate=26 July 2012}}</ref> He eventually made his third appearance for Derby four days later as a half-time substitute for Fielding away at [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]]; Derby won 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17711036 |title=Portsmouth 1–2 Derby |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2012 |accessdate=21 April 2012}}</ref> He started the final game of the season, a 1–1 draw against [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17796190 |title=Derby 1–1 Peterborough |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2012 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref>
Legzdins again started the season as second-choice goalkeeper. After Fielding picked a groin injury in October, Legzdins returned to the starting line-up and kept his place after Fielding regained fitness in November.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/Derby-County-goalkeeper-Adam-Legzdins-set-stay/story-17402691-detail/story.html |title=Derby County goalkeeper Adam Legzdins set to stay at number one spot when Birmingham City visit Pride Park Stadium |first=Steve |last=Nicholson |newspaper=Derby Telegraph |date=23 November 2012 |accessdate=12 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923224745/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-County-goalkeeper-Adam-Legzdins-set-stay/story-17402691-detail/story.html |archivedate=23 September 2015}}</ref> He impressed Clough with his performances, especially in the 2–0 win at [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] which ended a run of seven consecutive games without a clean sheet and a run of four away defeats.<ref name="briscgame">{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/Keeper-Adam-Legzdins-deserved-clean-sheet-seven/story-17608832-detail/story.html |title=Keeper Adam Legzdins deserved first clean sheet in seven, says boss |newspaper=Derby Telegraph |date=17 December 2012 |accessdate=12 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140519150242/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Keeper-Adam-Legzdins-deserved-clean-sheet-seven/story-17608832-detail/story.html |archivedate=19 May 2014}}</ref> Saves against [[Steve Davies (footballer born 1987)|Steve Davies]] and [[Liam Fontaine]] were picked out by Clough, with one from Fontaine described as one "down to pure size and presence, as well as quick feet to get across his line and block it. It was a very important save."<ref name="briscgame"/> Legzdins' run of 30 consecutive first-team starts ended in March 2013 when Clough felt the need for Fielding's greater experience ahead of Derby's 2–1 win against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/Centre-halves-won-Leicester-game-says-Derby/story-18449567-detail/story.html |title=Centre-halves 'won us the Leicester game,' says Derby County's Nigel Clough |newspaper=Derby Telegraph |date=18 March 2013 |accessdate=12 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526021548/http://www.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/Centre-halves-won-Leicester-game-says-Derby/story-18449567-detail/story.html |archivedate=26 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Five weeks later, Legzdins returned to first-team action after Fielding was sent off for a professional foul against Peterborough United,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22133302 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Derby 3–1 Peterborough |date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> and he started the final two games of the season, ending the season with 33 first-team appearances. After Derby signed [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]'s [[Lee Grant (footballer born 1983)|Lee Grant]] in May, Legzdins was made available for transfer with a year left on his contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Rams-listen-offers-Fielding-Legzdins/story-18914541-detail/story.html |newspaper=Derby Telegraph |first=Steve |last=Nicholson |title=Rams will listen to offers for Fielding and Legzdins |date=8 May 2013 |accessdate=12 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924002512/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Rams-listen-offers-Fielding-Legzdins/story-18914541-detail/story.html |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Legzdins was originally not given a squad number for the [[2013–14 Derby County F.C. season|2013–14 season]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dcfc.co.uk/news/article/2013-14-squad-numbers-announced-915805.aspx |publisher=Derby County F.C. |title=2013–14 squad numbers announced|date=15 July 2013}}</ref> However, after featuring in first-team pre-season friendlies he was assigned the squad number 26 in late July and went into the season as second choice to Grant.
===Leyton Orient=== Legzdins signed for [[Football League One|League One]] club [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on 13 June 2014. He signed a two-year contract with the East London club after being released by Derby.<ref>{{cite news |title=Adam Legzdins: Leyton Orient sign Derby County goalkeeper |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27835791 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 June 2014 |accessdate=13 June 2014}}</ref> He left the club by mutual consent on 1 June 2015 after his appearances during the 2014–15 season were restricted by injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32962766 |title=Adam Legzdins: Leyton Orient terminate keeper's contract |date=1 June 2015 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
===Birmingham City=== [[File:Legzdins.png|thumb|upright|Legzdins warming up for [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in 2015]] Legzdins re-joined [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on 27 June 2015; he signed a two-year deal with the option of a further year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33298887 |title=Adam Legzdins: Birmingham City sign goalkeeper |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 June 2015 |accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> On the bench for the opening league match of the season{{snd}}[[Tomasz Kuszczak]] started{{snd}}Legzdins made his Birmingham debut three days later in a 2–1 League Cup win away to [[Bristol Rovers]].<ref name=sb1516/> He played in two more cup matches before finally making his League debut for Birmingham on 9 April 2016; he kept a clean sheet in a 2–0 win away to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], and finished the season with nine appearances, of which five were inn the league.<ref name=sb1516/>
He made his first league appearance of the [[2016–17 Birmingham City F.C. season|2016–17 season]] when Kuszczak succumbed to a pre-existing injury during the warm-up before Birmingham's match away to Reading on 13 September; he kept a clean sheet in a goalless draw.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-boss-gary-rowett-11883348 |title=Birmingham City boss Gary Rowett on Adam Legzdins' first team prospects after surprise chance |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=13 September 2016 |accessdate=14 September 2016}}</ref> He kept his place for the next seven matches, even after Kuszczak's return to fitness,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-boss-gary-rowett-12059078 |title=Birmingham City boss Gary Rowett gives his thoughts on Adam Legzdins |first=Joseph |last=Chapman |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=21 October 2016 |accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> but manager [[Gary Rowett]] brought Kuszczak back into the side for the [[Second City derby|local derby]] against [[Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-boss-gary-rowett-12103526 |title=Birmingham City boss Gary Rowett discusses decision to drop Adam Legzdins |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=31 October 2016 |accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> He made four more appearances in the second half of the season: two in the FA Cup,<ref name=sb1617/> and two in the league, on both occasions as a half-time substitute for the injured Kuszczak.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-gianfranco-zola-head-12487264 |title=Birmingham City: Gianfranco Zola on the head injury to Tomasz Kuszczak |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=21 January 2017 |accessdate=8 May 2017}}<br>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/report?gameId=452702 |title=Birmingham City 0–2 Burton Albion |publisher=ESPN |agency=PA Sport |date=17 April 2017 |accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref> When Birmingham took up their option to extend his contract for a further year, Legzdins said he was "absolutely delighted" to accept, in preference to offers from elsewhere, "because everybody who knows me knows how much the club means to me."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/adam-legzdins-happy-pick-birmingham-13099396 |title=Adam Legzdins happy to pick Birmingham City over other offers |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=27 May 2017 |accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref>
===Burnley=== The arrival of [[David Stockdale]] left Legzdins third in Birmingham's pecking order for 2017–18, and [[Premier League]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] were in need of a goalkeeper after [[Paul Robinson (footballer, born 1979)|Paul Robinson]]'s retirement left them without sufficient backup for [[Tom Heaton]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.burtonmail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/ex-burton-albion-goalkeeper-adam-297582 |title=Ex-Burton Albion goalkeeper Adam Legzdins linked with Premier League move away from Birmingham City |first=Josh |last=Murray |newspaper=Burton Mail |date=8 August 2017 |accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref> On 8 August 2017, Legzdins signed a three-year contract with Burnley; the fee was undisclosed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2017/august/clarets-sign-legzdins/ |title=Clarets sign Legzdins |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=8 August 2017 |accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref>

Wells began his career in his native Bermuda, playing for [[Dandy Town Hornets F.C.|Dandy Town Hornets]] and [[Bermuda Hogges F.C.|Bermuda Hogges]]. After moving to England, where he had a brief spell in non-league football with [[Eccleshill United F.C.|Eccleshill United]], Wells has since played in [[the Football League]] for [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]], [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] and Huddersfield Town. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Wells was born in [[Hamilton, Bermuda|Hamilton]]. Retrieved 8 January 2012. On 9 March 2012, Bradford City exercised an option in Wells' contract, and extended his deal by one year.{{cite web|url=http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10266~2642269,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120630224803/http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10266~2642269,00.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 June 2012|title=City take up Wells option|date=9 March 2012|publisher=Bradford City A.F.C.}} On 14 April, he scored a hat-trick as Bradford beat [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] 3–1.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17643373 "Northampton 1–3 Bradford"] BBC Sport. 14 April 2012. Retrieved 14 April 2012. He was later named in the Football League Two Team of the Week for that week.[http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10266~1784558,00.html "Wells named in FL Team of the Week"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228172424/http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/page/News/0%2C%2C10266~1784558%2C00.html |date=28 February 2012 }} Bradford City F.C. 17 April 2012.
