web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10601936.All_quiet_on_Bradford_City_frontman_Wells/|title=All quiet on Bradford City frontman Nahki Wells|date=9 August 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} In August 2013, Wells' strike partner Hanson spoke positively of his partnership with Wells.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10601939.Bradford_City_strike_pair_One_to_watch/|title=Bradford City strike pair James Hanson and Nahki Wells One to watch|date=9 August 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} On 24 August 2013, Wells scored two goals in a home match against Sheffield United; in the process he set a new club record by scoring in his eighth consecutive match, a feat which was praised by teammate James Hanson.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10633834.Hanson_thrilled_to_play_alongside_record_breaking_Bradford_City_forward_partner_Wells/|title=James Hanson thrilled to play alongside record-breaking Bradford City forward partner Nahki Wells|date=26 August 2013|accessdate=27 August 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} After the match the club re-stated that they would not sell Wells,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10633630.Parkin__Bradford_City_won_t_sell_Wells/|title=Parkin: Bradford City won't sell Wells|date=24 August 2013|accessdate=24 August 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10636891.Wells_is_going_nowhere__insists_Bradford_City_boss/|title=Nahki Wells is going nowhere, insists Bradford City boss Phil Parkinson|date=28 August 2013|accessdate=2 September 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10642811.Bradford_City_strike_sensation_Wells_staying__cool__amid_transfer_hype/|title=Bradford City strike sensation Nahki Wells staying 'cool' amid transfer hype|date=30 August 2013|accessdate=2 September 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} and later confirmed they had not received any bids for the player on transfer deadline day.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10647671.Bradford_City__We_ve_had_no_Wells_bids_today/|title=Bradford City: We've had no Wells bids today|date=2 September 2013|accessdate=2 September 2013|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} On 4 September 2013, Wells was nominated for the League One Player of the Month award,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10652473.Wells_nominated_for_Football_League_prize/|title=Bradford City striker Nahki Wells nominated for Football League prize|date=4 September 2013|accessdate=4 September 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} winning the award two days later.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10658455.Bantams_award_winner_Wells__Team_the_real_prize_guys/|title=Bantams League One player of month Nahki Wells says team the real prize guys|date=6 September 2013|accessdate=6 September 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} Wells has publicly praised his strike partnership with Hanson,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10671292.Bantams_hitman_Wells_on_why_he_and_Hanson_are_such_a_striking_combination/|title=Bantams hitman Nahki Wells gives the lowdown on why he and James Hanson are such a striking combination|date=13 September 2013|accessdate=13 September 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} as has journalist Simon Parker, who described them as "[one of] the best front pairs that League One has to offer."{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10816720.Bradford_City__Wells_plus_Hanson_equals_must_see_TV/|title=Bradford City: Nahki Wells plus James Hanson equals must-see TV|date=19 November 2013|accessdate=19 November 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} Of the 53 goals that Wells scored for Bradford City, 49 came when he was playing with Hanson.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10932591.Bradford_City__Death_of_a_double_act_but_Hanson_looks_to_the_future/|title=Bradford City: Death of a double act but James Hanson looks to the future after Nahki Wells departure|date=14 January 2014|accessdate=15 January 2014|author=Andrew Davies|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} In late September 2013 Wells suffered ankle ligament damage in a match, and was ruled out for a number of weeks.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10709385.Nahki_Wells_suffers_ankle_ligament_damage/|title=Nahki Wells suffers ankle ligament damage|date=1 October 2013|accessdate=1 October 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} Manager Phil Parkinson stated he would not rush Wells back into play,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10751072.Bradford_City_boss_Parkinson_will_not_rush_Wells__comeback/|title=Bradford City boss Phil Parkinson will not rush Nahki Wells' comeback|date=21 October 2013|accessdate=24 October 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} Wells returned, after two months out, to score a hat-trick against Coventry City.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10815306.Wells_helps_Bradford_City_see_the_light/|title=Nahki Wells helps Bradford City see the light|date=18 November 2013|accessdate=18 November 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} In December 2013, club co-chairman [[Julian Rhodes]] admitted that the player might leave the club,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10852569.Chances_of_signing_Bradford_City_striker_Wells_on_new_long_term_deal_unlikely__admits_Rhodes/|title=Chances of signing Bradford City striker Nahki Wells on new long-term deal unlikely, admits Julian Rhodes|date=4 December 2013|accessdate=4 December 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} as rumours surrounding the player's possible departure began to increase.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10860925.Wells_rumour_mill_set_to_go_into_overdrive_but_Bantams_just_being_shrewd_in_keeping_bases_open/|title=Nahki Wells rumour mill set to go into overdrive but Bantams just being shrewd in keeping their bases open|date=7 December 2013|accessdate=8 December 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} That same month, colleague Andrew Davies described Wells and Hanson as the best strike pair in the division,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10858057.Wells_and_Hanson_a_deadly_double_act_for_Bradford_City/|title=Nahki Wells and James Hanson a deadly double act for Bradford City|date=6 December 2013|accessdate=8 December 2013|author=Andrew Davies|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} and Davies also urged Wells to remain with the club,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10857668.Davies__Wells_can_achieve_ambitions_staying_at_Bradford_City/|title=Andrew Davies: Nahki Wells can achieve ambitions staying at Bradford City|date=6 December 2013|accessdate=8 December 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} while manager Phil Parkinson said that he did not want the club to sell the player.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10878682.I_m_hoping_for_an_offer_we_can_refuse__Bantams_boss_keeping_his_fingers_crossed_no_mega_bucks_bids_come_in_for_Wells/|title=I'm hoping for an offer we can refuse! Bantams boss keeping his fingers crossed no mega-bucks bids come in for Nahki Wells|date=16 December 2013|accessdate=17 December 2013|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} Wells picked up an injury at the end of December 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10904645.Bradford_City_hopeful_on_Wells_injury/|title=Bradford City hopeful on Wells injury|date=30 December 2013|accessdate=2 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} and at the start of the January 2014 transfer window, manager Phil Parkinson said he wanted any transfer issues sorted quickly.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10908244.I_don___t_want_to_play_waiting_game_over_Wells_in_transfer_window__says_Bradford_City_boss/|title=Nahki Wells in transfer window, says Bradford City boss Phil Parkinson|date=2 January 2014|accessdate=2 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} The next day, 3 January 2014, the club announced that they had already rejected one offer for the player,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10911090.Bradford_City_refuse_first_Wells_offer/|title=Bradford City refuse first January offer for Nahki Wells|date=3 January 2014|accessdate=3 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} after saying that Wells has been receiving interest from a number of [[Premier League]] clubs,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10919235.Bradford_City_striker_Wells_attracting_Premier_interest/|title=Bradford City striker Nahki Wells attracting Premier interest|date=8 January 2014|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} as well as Championship side Burnley.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10922609.Burnley_latest_club_to_be_linked_with_Bradford_City_hot_shot_Wells/|title=Burnley latest club to be linked with Bradford City hot-shot Nahki Wells|date=9 January 2014|accessdate=9 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} The club also said they would lose £1 million for the 2013–14 season if they did not sell Wells.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10913274.Nahki_Wells_future_a_dilemma_for_Bradford_City_finances/|title=Nahki Wells future a dilemma for Bradford City finances|date=4 January 2014|accessdate=5 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} Despite all the speculation, Parkinson said he felt Wells would be able to ignore off-the-field matters and concentrate on his playing,{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10914932.Parkinson_sure_in_demand_Wells_will_not_let_Bradford_City_down/|title=Phil Parkinson sure in-demand Nahki Wells will not let Bradford City down|date=6 January 2014|accessdate=7 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} though he later admitted that the player was being affected by the rumours.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10927726.Bradford_City_boss_says_speculation_affecting_Nahki_Wells/|title=Bradford City boss Phil Parkinson says speculation affecting form of Nahki Wells|date=10 January 2014|accessdate=10 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} ===Huddersfield Town=== On 10 January 2014, Wells signed a four-and-a-half-year contract with [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] after transferring for an undisclosed club record fee.{{cite web|url=http://www.htafc.com/news/article/first-team-news-nahki-wells-signs-1286689.aspx|title=TERRIERS SIGN WELLS|date=10 January 2014|accessdate=10 January 2014|publisher=Huddersfield Town A.F.C.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/news/article/wells-moves-to-huddersfield-town-1285097.aspx|title=Wells moves to Huddersfield|date=10 January 2014|accessdate=10 January 2014|publisher=Bradford City A.F.C.}} The deal was initially completed a one-game loan deal, to allow time for the paperwork for the permanent move to be completed.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10928586.Huddersfield_boss_plays_down_Wells_transfer_talk/|title=UPDATED: Wells joins Huddersfield from Bradford City|date=10 January 2014|accessdate=10 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25682217|title=Transfer window: Huddersfield sign Bradford's Nahki Wells|date=10 January 2014|accessdate=10 January 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}} Wells was criticised by a section for moving from Bradford City to a team considered a rival.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10930446.Bradford_City_fans_urged_to_respect_departing_Wells____ambition/|title=Bradford City fans urged to respect departing Nahki Wells' ambition|date=11 January 2014|accessdate=12 January 2014|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} On 11 January 2014, Wells made his Huddersfield Town debut, appearing as a substitute in the 55th minute, and scoring the winning goal in a 1–0 home victory against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], less than 24 hours after joining the club.{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/huddersfield/huddersfield-1-millwall-0-wells-nets-winner-on-debut-1-6367394|title=Huddersfield 1 Millwall 0: Wells nets winner on debut|date=11 January 2014|accessdate=12 January 2014|publisher=Yorkshire Post}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10931519.Robins_hails__absolute_snip__Nahki_Wells__winning_strike/|title=Mark Robins hails 'absolute snip' Nahki Wells' winning strike|date=13 January 2014|accessdate=13 January 2014|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} Wells ended his first full-season with Huddersfield Town as the club's top scorer with 14 goals.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/teams/huddersfield-town/top-scorers|title=Top Scorers – Huddersfield Town – Football|website=BBC Sport}} At the end of the 2016–17 season, former club Bradford City received a £250,000 bonus payment following Huddersfield's promotion to the Premier League.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/15278097.Wells_windfall_waits_for_Bantams___if_Huddersfield_go_up/|title=Wells windfall waits for Bantams – if Huddersfield go up|website=Bradford Telegraph and Argus}} ===Burnley=== Wells, in the final year of his contract with Huddersfield, signed a three-year deal with [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] for £5 million on 31 August 2017.{{cite web|last1=Ferrington|first1=Juliette|title=Nahki Wells: Burnley sign striker from Huddersfield|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41098534|website=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 August 2017|date=31 August 2017}} ===Queens Park Rangers=== On 23 August 2018, Wells signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45286047|title=QPR: Brighton's Tomer Hemed and Burnley's Nahki Wells join on loan|date=23 August 2018|accessdate=24 August 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}} He scored his first goal for QPR against [[Sheffield Wednesday]] on 23 October 2018. ==International career== Wells made his international debut for [[Bermuda national football team|Bermuda]] in 2007. Wells also made four unofficial international appearances for Bermuda in the [[International Island Games Association|2007 Island Games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rhodesresults2007.com/Competitor.aspx?RegID=9486|title=Nahki Wells|accessdate=21 December 2010|publisher=NatWest Island Games XII}} In late August 2011, Wells was recalled by Bermuda, joining their squad for FIFA World Cup qualifying matches in early September 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10266~2429353,00.html|title=Wells given Bermuda call up|accessdate=23 August 2011|date=23 August 2011|publisher=Bradford City A.F.C.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905185218/http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10266~2429353,00.html|archivedate=5 September 2012|df=dmy-all}} Wells appeared in five 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifying matches for Bermuda,{{FIFA player|295034}} against [[Barbados national football team|Barbados]], [[Guyana national football team|Guyana]] and [[Trinidad and Tobago national football team|Trinidad and Tobago]]. Wells was described as "one of Bermuda's most promising players, with an exceptionally bright future" in February 2012 by then Sports Minister [[Glenn Blakeney]],{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/9514779.Wells_doing_his_bit_for_club_and_country/|title=Bradford City striker Nahki Wells happy to be role model if it helps develop Bermuda football|date=7 February 2012|author=Simon Parker|work=Telegraph & Argus}} and was honoured by Premier [[Craig Cannonier]] in June 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10464826.Wells_honoured_for_Bradford_City_exploits/|title=Nahki Wells honoured after Bradford City exploits|date=5 June 2013|author=Ross Heppenstall|work=Telegraph & Argus}} He has been described as the country's "star footballer".{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/sportbcfc/10916913.Bermuda_crazy_for_news_of_Bradford_City_striker_Wells/|title=Bermuda crazy for news of Bradford City striker Nahki Wells|date=7 {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Aiden O'Neill | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Aiden Connor O'Neill{{cite news|url=http://www.efl.com/news/article/2016/efl-club-retained-and-released-lists-published-3151313.aspx|publisher=[[English Football League]]|accessdate=22 August 2016|date=23 June 2016|title=EFL: Club retained and released lists published}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1998|7|4|df=y}}{{cite web|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/team/player-profile/aiden-o-neill/41|title=Burnley Football Club – First Team|website=www.burnleyfootballclub.com}} | birth_place = [[Brisbane]], Australia | height = {{height|m=1.78}}{{cite web |title=Aiden O'Neill |url=http://www.11v11.com/players/aiden-oneill-253607/ |work=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=26 April 2017}} | currentclub = [[Central Coast Mariners FC|Central Coast Mariners]]
(on loan from [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]) | clubnumber = 13 | position = [[Midfielder|Central midfielder]] | youthyears1 = 2004–2006 | youthclubs1 = [[University of Queensland FC|Kenmore]] | youthyears2 = 2007–2011 | youthclubs2 = Brisbane Athletic | youthyears3 = 2014–2016 | youthclubs3 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | years1 = 2016– | clubs1 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps1 = 3 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2017 | clubs2 = → [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] (loan) | caps2 = 15 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2017–2018 | clubs3 = → [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] (loan) | caps3 = 21 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[Central Coast Mariners FC|Central Coast Mariners]] (loan) | caps4 = 19 | goals4 = 4 | nationalyears1 = 2017– | nationalteam1 = [[Australia national under-23 soccer team|Australia U23]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 18:41, 17 February 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 20:24, 15 January 2018 (UTC) }} '''Aiden Connor O'Neill''' (born 4 July 1998) is an Australian professional [[association football|football]] player who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Central Coast Mariners FC|Central Coast Mariners]] in the [[A-League]], on loan from [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]. Born in Brisbane, O'Neill played youth football for Brisbane Athletic and [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] before making his professional debut for the latter in 2016. He spent some time on loan to [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] and [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]], scoring his first ever professional goal for the latter club. He returned to Australia, on loan, to play for [[Central Coast Mariners FC|Central Coast Mariners]] in 2018. He has represented the [[Australia national under-23 soccer team|Australian under-23 national team]]. ==Early life== O'Neill is of Irish ancestry. He was born and raised in Brisbane, attending Nudgee Junior College before moving to [[Brisbane Boys' College]] before moving to England aged fourteen when his parents moved there for work.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/football/aiden-oneill-credits-a-dog-with-honing-his-attacking-skills/news-story/7df66fa3408e206bccb6358ce9d63467?login=1|title=Aiden O'Neill credits a dog with honing his attacking skills|publisher=''[[The Australian]]''|date=17 June 2017|accessdate=18 June 2017|author=Gatt, Ray}} ==Career== O'Neill played youth football for Brisbane Athletic between 2008 and 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/brisbaneathleticfc/photos/a.223634841178333.1073741835.191833267691824/499477400260741/?type=3&theater|title=Brisbane Athletic Football Club|publisher=[[Facebook]]|date=23 August 2016|accessdate=23 August 2016}} He moved to England as a teenager, where he sought to pursue a career in football.{{cite news|url=http://www.footballaustralia.com.au/article/the-story-behind-burnleys-epl-debutant-from-australia/103t1yfkxmvkf1na0dy53az6qg|title=The story behind Burnley's EPL debutant from Australia|publisher=[[Football Federation Australia]]|date=25 August 2016|accessdate=28 August 2016}} On 12 January 2016, O'Neill signed his first professional contract with then-[[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].{{cite news|title=O'Neill Signs Professional Deal|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/oneill-signs-professional-deal-2897325.aspx|accessdate=20 August 2016|work=Burnley Football Club|date=12 January 2016}} He made his professional debut for the club on 20 August 2016, coming on as a late substitute against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the [[Premier League]] as Burnley won 2–0.{{cite web|title=Burnley 2–0 Liverpool|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/08/20/england/premier-league/burnley-fc/liverpool-fc/2242031/|website=Soccerway}} He made his full debut days later, starting in an [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]] loss to [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] in the [[EFL Cup]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37103144|publisher=[[BBC Sports]]|date=24 August 2016|accessdate=25 August 2016|title=Accrington Stanley 1–0 Burnley (AET)}} In January 2017, he joined [[EFL League One]] strugglers [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on loan until the end of the season.{{Cite news |title=O'Neill Makes Loan Move To Oldham |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/2016-17/oneill-makes-loan-move-to-oldham-3548336.aspx |publisher=Burnley Official Site |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=31 January 2017}} He made a total of fifteen appearances for the Latics. In August 2017, he joined League One side [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] on a season-long loan deal.{{Cite news |title=Aiden O'Neill: Fleetwood Town sign Burnley midfielder on season-long loan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40789649 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 August 2017 |accessdate=14 August 2017}} In January 2018, he returned to Burnley early having made twenty-seven appearances and scoring once against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].{{Cite news |title=Aiden O'Neill returns to Burnley|url=https://www.fleetwoodtownfc.com/news/2018/january/aiden-oneill-returns-to-burnley/ |publisher=Fleetwood Town F.C. |date=2 January 2018 |accessdate=9 January 2018}} In August 2018, O'Neill returned to Australia to play for [[Central Coast Mariners FC|Central Coast Mariners]] in the [[A-League]] on a season-long loan.{{cite news|date=15 August 2018|accessdate=15 August 2018|title=Burnley midfielder O'Neill returns home to Central Coast Mariners|url=https://www.burnleyexpress.net/sport/football/clarets/burnley-midfielder-o-neill-returns-home-to-central-coast-mariners-1-9301886|publisher=''[[Burnley Express]]''|author=Boden, Chris}} ==International career== O'Neill has stated that his preference is to play for Australia, but had not been in any contact with [[Football Federation Australia]] when he made his Premier League debut in August 2016.{{cite news|url=http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/article/2016/09/02/premier-league-whizkid-oneill-dreaming-socceroos-call|title=Premier League whizkid O'Neill dreaming of Socceroos call|publisher=''[[The World Game]]''|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=3 September 2016|author=Lewis, Dave}} He was later called up for an [[Australia national under-23 soccer team|Australia under-23]] camp in March 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/football/deni-juric-the-younger-brother-of-socceroos-striker-tomi-selected-for-olyroos-camp-in-spain/news-story/c3fb827ec291f3913266a609b3f872ec|title=Deni Juric, the younger brother of Socceroos striker Tomi, selected for Olyroos camp in Spain|author=Davutovic, David|publisher=''[[Herald Sun]]''|date=15 March 2017|accessdate=13 June 2017}} He had previously been contacted by the [[Football Association of Ireland]] and the [[Irish Football Association]] but reiterated that his preference was to play for Australia. ==Career statistics== '''James Dunne''' (3 September 1905 – 14 November 1949) was an Irish [[association football|footballer]] who played for, among others, [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]], [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]. Dunne was also a [[dual Irish international footballers|dual internationalist]] and played for both Ireland teams: the [[Irish Free State national football team|FAI XI]] and the [[Ireland national football team (IFA)|IFA XI]]. Dunne holds the all-time record of consecutive goals scored at the elite level of English football.
Dunne was the first Irishman to figure prominently in the [[Football League|English League]] scoring records. In the [[1930–31 in English football|1930–31]] season he scored 41 league goals for [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]. This became a club record and remains the most league goals scored by an Irishman during a single English League season.
In the [[1931–32 in English football|1931–32]] season, he scored in 12 consecutive matches. This is the all-time record of consecutive goals scored at the elite level of English football. Dunne also scored 30 or more [[Football League First Division|First Division]] goals in three consecutive seasons between 1930 and 1933. He excelled at either centre forward or inside forward and was outstanding with his head. On 27 September 1930 he scored a [[hat-trick]] of headers against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]]. He was a fringe member of the great [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] side of the 1930s before finishing his career at [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]].
Dunne died suddenly from a heart attack, at the age of 44, on 14 November 1949. His two sons, [[Tommy Dunne (footballer born 1932)|Tommy]] and [[Jimmy Dunne (footballer born 1935)|Jimmy]], also played in the [[League of Ireland]] for [[St. Patrick's Athletic F.C.|St. Patrick's Athletic]]. Tommy also played for [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]]. His nephew, [[Tommy Dunne (footballer born 1927)|another Tommy Dunne]], also played for Rovers and another nephew [[Christy Doyle]], played for [[Shelbourne F.C.|Shelbourne]] and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]].
==Club career==
===Early years=== Dunne initially played junior football. However his career was put on hold during the [[Irish Civil War]] when he was interned by the [[Irish Free State]] authorities for alleged [[Irish republicanism|Republican]] sympathies. His brother, Christy, was an active Republican. He subsequently joined [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]] and played a number of games for the club's senior team. A scout recommended him to [[New Brighton A.F.C.|New Brighton]], then playing in the [[Football League Third Division North|English Third Division North]]. Dunne joined New Brighton in November 1925 and made an instant impact, scoring six goals in eight league games.<ref name="The FAI International Story 1997">''The Boys in Green – The FAI International Story'' (1997): Sean Ryan ({{ISBN|978-1-85158-939-5}})</ref><ref name = "NIF">[http://nifootball.blogspot.com/2006/11/jimmy-dunne.html Northern Ireland's Footballing Greats]</ref>
===Sheffield United=== Dunne soon attracted the interest of [[Football League First Division|First Division]] side [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] who signed him in February 1926 for £800. However this marked the start of another apprenticeship in the reserves. He made his first team debut in a 4–0 home win against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 4 September 1926 but he struggled to hold a regular place and in his first three seasons played just eleven league games. His first goal came against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 15 October 1927. Dunne had to wait three years before he became an established member of the United team and at one stage they put him on the transfer list. It was not until the [[1929–30 in English football#First Division|1929–30]] season that Dunne became a goalscoring sensation. His first hat-trick against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in a 3–3 draw on 7 September 1929 was followed by successive four-goal hauls against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on New Year's Day (4–2) and [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] (7–1) three days later. He scored another hat-trick against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 3 March. He finished the season as the club's top goalscorer with 36 goals in 39 games and his goals helped United avoid relegation on goal average.
Dunne was subsequently top goalscorer at United for four consecutive seasons between 1929 and 1933. This included scoring over 30 [[Football League First Division|First Division]] goals in three consecutive seasons between 1930 and 1933. His best season was [[1930–31 in English football|1930–31]], when he scored 41 league goals plus a further nine in other competitions; his 41-goal haul remains the record tally in the English League by an Irishman. Dunne holds the all-time record of goals scored in consecutive matches at the elite level of English football: between 24 October 1931 and 1 January 1932, he scored in 12 games in succession.<ref name = "NIF"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Jamie Vardy to Cristiano Ronaldo: Weird & wonderful goal records|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34402082|accessdate=22 November 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 November 2015}}</ref>
===Arsenal=== Dunne's goalscoring form with [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] soon attracted the interest of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. In early 1932 they offered United £10,000 for Dunne but were turned down. However, in September 1933, after United hit financial trouble, they accepted a reduced fee of £8,250. Dunne made his debut for Arsenal against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 30 September 1933 in a 6–0 win, and went on to score 9 goals in 23 league games during the [[1933–34 in English football#First Division|1933–34]] season, helping Arsenal win the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] title. However, the arrival of [[Ted Drake]] in the summer of 1934 saw Dunne lose his place in the Arsenal first team, and he would only play another 8 games over the next two seasons. Dunne was dubbed "the most expensive reserve player in English football" in the press, although his Arsenal colleagues clearly recognised his talents, with [[Cliff Bastin]] remarking he was "one of the best five centre forwards I had ever seen".<ref name = "NIF"/>
===Southampton=== In July 1936 Dunne signed for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] where he was nicknamed "Snowy" by the fans because of his fair hair.<ref name = ABC>{{cite book |title=The Alphabet of the Saints|last= Holley |first= Duncan |last2= Chalk|first2= Gary|publisher= ACL & Polar Publishing|year=1992|isbn=0-9514862-3-3|page=111}}</ref> Described as "dangerous in the air (with) a short striding run which enabled him to retain his balance in quick moves near the goal",<ref name = ABC/> he was the Saints' leading scorer during the [[1936–37 in English football#Second Division|1936–37]] season, scoring 14 league goals in 36 games, helping Southampton to avoid relegation to the Third Division.<ref>{{cite book | title=Saints – A complete record|last= Chalk|first= Gary|last2=Holley|first2= Duncan | publisher= Breedon Books|year=1987|isbn= 0-907969-22-4|pages=96–97}}</ref>
At the end of the season, Dunne turned down the opportunity to renew his contract at Southampton and opted to return to [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]].<ref name = ABC/> Eighteen months after leaving the club, Dunne was given a rousing salute by Southampton dockers as he passed through the port with the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Ireland]] team.<ref name = "NIF"/><ref name = ABC/>
===Shamrock Rovers=== In 1937 Dunne returned to [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]] as player-manager and was the inspiration behind Rovers winning [[League of Ireland]] titles in 1938 and 1939. He won 9 caps during this spell at Milltown. He also helped Rovers win the [[FAI Cup]] in 1940. The reserves had won the Leinster Senior League Division 1 title that season and they were coached by Dunne whose first medal with Rovers was the Leinster Senior League Division 1.
On 31 August 1942 Rovers played [[Belfast Celtic]] in a testimonial for Dunne which ended in a 2–2 draw. Dunne went on to coach [[Bohemian F.C.|Bohemians]] between 1942 and 1947 before returning to Rovers once again.<ref>[http://www.shamrockrovers.ie/history.php www.shamrockrovers.ie] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801163442/http://www.shamrockrovers.ie/history.php |date= 1 August 2008 }}</ref> <ref>[http://www.belfastceltic.net/archive/hoops.html www.belfastceltic.net]</ref>
==Irish international== When Dunne began his international career in 1928 there were, in effect, two Ireland teams, chosen by two rival associations. Both associations, the [[Northern Ireland]] – based [[Irish Football Association|IFA]] and the [[Irish Free State]] – based [[Football Association of Ireland|FAI]] claimed jurisdiction over the whole of Ireland and selected players from the whole island. As a result, several notable Irish players from this era, including Dunne, played for both teams.
===IFA XI=== Between [[1928 British Home Championship|1928]] and 1932 Dunne made 7 appearances and scored 4 goals for the [[Ireland national football team (IFA)|IFA XI]]. Dunne made his debut for the IFA XI on 2 February 1928 in a 2–1 defeat against [[Wales national football team|Wales]]. He won his second cap for the IFA XI on 20 October [[1931 British Home Championship|1930]] against [[England national football team|England]] and scored in a 5–1 defeat. During 1931 he scored a further three goals for the IFA XI and as a result scored 4 goals in four consecutive appearances.<ref name = "NIF"/>
===FAI XI=== Between 1930 and 1939 Dunne also made 15 appearances and scored 13 goals for the [[Irish Free State national football team|FAI XI]]. He made his debut for the FAI XI on 11 May 1930 in an away game against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]]. Dunne marked his debut with a brilliant all round performance, scoring twice in a 3–1 win. He also scored on his home debut for the FAI XI on 17 March 1936 in a 1–0 win against [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]]. In May 1936, during a European tour, he scored five goals for the FAI XI. On 3 May he scored twice in a 3–3 draw with [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]]. On 3 May he also scored in a 4–1 defeat to a Rhineland XI and then on 9 May scored twice in a 5–1 win against [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]]. On 10 October 1937 Dunne scored for the FAI XI in a [[1938 FIFA World Cup qualification|World Cup]] qualifier against [[Norway national football team|Norway]]. Norway, who won the game 3–2, later complained that Dunne was ineligible, having played for the IFA XI, who were not members of [[FIFA]]. The complaint was subsequently withdraw and on 7 November, Dunne scored in the return which finished as a 3–3 draw. He scored his last goal for the FAI XI in a 3–2 win over [[Poland national football team|Poland]] on 13 November 1938 and made his final appearance against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] on 23 May 1939.<ref name="The FAI International Story 1997"/><ref>[http://www.soccerscene.ie/sssenior/player.php?id=246 Ireland (FAI) stats]</ref>
